status_message: Republican New Yorkers signed up for Trump's plans of repealing the First and Eighth Amendments -- rights that shape American beliefs.
link_name: What GOP New Yorkers Just Voted For: Torture, Syria Intervention and the Murder of Innocents

status_message: Not only was March record warm, but the planet is having its hottest year to date by a significant margin.
link_name: March Continues Streak of Exceptional Global Warmth

status_message:
New York primary –> Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton won by big margins last night. While both were projected to win, the margin of victory, particularly on the Democratic side, was a surprise. Clinton won New York City, the suburbs to the north, and the state's other urban centers while Sanders carried the rest. Trump won the Republican vote in every single county except one: his own Manhattan.

The Washington Post's Philip Bump writes that Clinton "won by undercutting Bernie Sanders's campaign both in delegates and in rhetoric." Jim Newell wonders at Slate.com whether Democrats will now unite around Clinton, noting that it seems the logical choice given her delegate lead — but not, necessarily, given her poll numbers: "Right at the moment that Sanders is struggling to make a necessary dig into Clinton's pledged-delegate lead, his national numbers are looking better than ever."
link_name: Morning Reads: Trump and Clinton Trounce Opponents in New York; State Struggles With Polling Chaos

status_message: Nuclear war, absent an immediate, fundamental, worldwide change in attitude, could be weeks, months or years away, writes Winslow Myers of the War Prevention Initiative.
link_name: The Inevitability of Nuclear War?

status_message: New York has some of the worst voting laws in the country, writes The Nation's Ari Berman.
link_name: 27 Percent of New York's Registered Voters Won't Be Able to Vote in the State's Primary

status_message: In the face of congressional inaction, protest leaders urge a focus on state and local battles.
link_name: For Democracy Marchers the Next Battle Is on the Home Front

status_message: The United States and China are leading a push to bring the Paris climate accord into force much faster than even the most optimistic projections – aided by a typographical glitch in the text of the agreement, writes The Guardian. More than 150 governments are expected at a symbolic signing ceremony for the agreement at the United Nations this Friday, which is #EarthDay.
link_name: US and China lead push to bring Paris climate deal into force early

status_message:
New York primary –> Empire State voters head to the polls today. Donald Trump is likely to carry the Republican vote by a large margin, with John Kasich coming in second. Ted Cruz seems to have thrown in the towel on a state that sneered right back at him after his snarky "New York values" comments — he's been busy campaigning elsewhere.

And, while Hillary Clinton leads among Democrats, high turnout would be a good sign for Bernie Sanders, although he is likely to be hurt by New York's dismal voter registration laws.
link_name: Morning Reads: New Yorkers Head to the Polls; US, China Push to Get Paris Agreement in Place Early

status_message: Congratulations to Lin-Manuel Miranda on his Pulitzer for Hamilton: An American Musical! According to The Daily Beast, it's only the 9th musical to win the award.
link_name: 'Hamilton' Wins Pulitzer Prize for Drama

status_message: "We have a tax system that reflects the interest of the one percent," Nobel Prize-winning economist Joseph Stiglitz tells Bill.
link_name: Joseph E. Stiglitz Calls for Fair Taxes for All

status_message: Bernie Sanders' popular campaign suggests that many Americans aren't afraid of socialism anymore. But "the false dichotomy of capitalism or socialism," should not be the election's framing issue, writes David Korten of YES! Magazine.
link_name: Capitalism or Socialism? There's an Even Better Option

status_message: Companies like H&R Block and Intuit are big spenders in Washington — and they're often arguing against making our tax returns easier.
link_name: How Lobbying by Tax-Preparers Helps Keep Tax Day Complicated

status_message:
More than 200 organizations united in Washington, DC on Sunday to fight for voting rights and campaign finance reform. Chanting "Our Capitol!" and "Our Congress!", an unusual mix of demonstrators managed to turn the too often esoteric issues of campaign finance and election law into matters worthy of genuine passion.

On Monday, demonstrators plan to continue to engage in civil disobedience outside the Capitol while others go inside to lobby members of Congress.
link_name: 'Our Congress:' Protesters Say Democracy Is Awakening

status_message:
What a mess! –> There's truth in Donald Trump's allegations of a broken, "rigged" election system, The New York Times editorial board writes. A confusing patchwork of election laws and scant resources for the agencies administering them puts a substantial burden on voters — including in New York State, which holds its primaries tomorrow: 

"New York lags behind more electorally advanced states in its refusal to allow voters the convenience of same-day registration, early voting and easier absentee balloting. The Republican ballot names the candidates while the confusing Democratic ballot asks voters to choose a candidate as well as delegates pledged to either of the two candidates."
link_name: Morning Reads: Why Is It So Hard to Vote in Progressive New York?

status_message:
The fossil fuel divestment movement continued its momentum this week as students across the United States highlighted the need for their institutions to dump "support of global climate disaster, exploitation, and human suffering." 

Bill interviewed two leaders of the fossil fuel divestment movement who are urging foundations, faith groups, pension funds, municipalities and universities to sell their shares in polluting industries and reinvest in companies committed to climate change solutions. You can see the interview here: http://bit.ly/1rrpn8H
link_name: Sit-Ins, Arrests, and Escalation: Student Divestment Movement Springs into Action

status_message: The media's failure to report on GOP efforts to suppress the vote is aiding and abetting a national disgrace, writes Neal Gabler.
link_name: The MSM Could Not Care Less About This Threat to Democracy

status_message:
"If we don't act on climate change, the world is not going to end in a flash and a bang. But what will end up happening is either my generation will feel the effects, where we have to fight for survival.. life will be very, very different. 

We won't be as privileged to live on the Earth. It will be a lot harder. But then also you think about, we're putting generations that haven't been born yet and generations to come in the position where they have to deal with that, and that's not a position anybody should be put in. And it's just not fair. So it's a moral, logical thing." -- Abi Piper, 15-year-old federal plaintiff, discussing a landmark climate lawsuit filed by Our Children's Trust on behalf of 21 young people.
link_name: Landmark Climate Lawsuit: Meet the Youth Activists Suing the U.S. Government & Fossil Fuel Industry

status_message: The federal government doesn't make it easy to find out where your tax money goes. That's why the National Priorities Project  has done the work for you.
link_name: The Surprising Truth Behind Tax Day: Where Your Taxes Go

status_message:
Church job seekers are being asked if they were sexually abused as children based on the false belief that victims will become abusers. The worst part - this discrimination is legal, writes Zack Kopplin. 

Kopplin spoke with Bill when he was 19 after receiving the Troublemaker Award for fighting on behalf of science and against laws making it easier to teach creationism in public schools. You can watch the interview here: http://bit.ly/1SGrqD0
link_name: Churches Ask Job Seekers: Were You Sexually Abused as a Child?

status_message:
It's one of the most popular and beloved songs in the English language. Transcending race, creed, geography, generation, and social station, "Amazing Grace" has been recorded more times than any other hymn and is widely credited with transforming lives. 

Bill Moyers explores the song's origins and enduring power in conversations with Johnny Cash, Judy Collins, Jean Ritchie, Jessye Norman and members of the Boys Choir of Harlem.
link_name: The Story of "Amazing Grace"

status_message: The visionary poet, environmentalist and farmer Wendell Berry reads and talks about two of his poems -- "The Contrariness of the Mad Farmer" and "A Poem on Hope." #PoetryMonth
link_name: Poetry Readings by Wendell Berry

status_message: Republicans talk about their decision to join the Democracy Spring  protests in Washington, DC this week.
link_name: Why Conservatives Are Marching for Campaign Finance Reform

status_message: A small core of super-rich individuals are responsible for the record sums cascading into the coffers of super PACs for the 2016 elections, a dynamic that harks back to the financing of presidential campaigns in the Gilded Age, according to a Washington Post analysis of federal campaign finance reports.
link_name: The new Gilded Age: Close to half of all super PAC money comes from 50 donors

status_message:
Bill Moyers: "If you want to know why this is the year of Trump, you've got to read Rick Shenkman's new book, Political Animals: How Our Stone-age Brain Gets in the Way of Smart Politics. If you want to know why millions of Republicans still believe Barack Obama is a Muslim, you've got to read it. Even if you want to hold on and remain an optimist, you've got to read it.

This week, I sat down with Rick Shenkman to talk about the brain of the American voter, and what is firing its synapses during this extraordinary primary season. 

Listen to our conversation. You can download it and take it with you, or read the full transcript, by clicking on the link below."
link_name: Voting With Their Stone-Age Brains - A Conversation Between Bill Moyers and Historian Rick Shenkman

status_message: It's been 15 years since Barbara Ehrenreich published her seminal book about what it's like to work for the minimum wage in America. Unfortunately, not much has changed.
link_name: Nickel and Dimed in 2016

status_message: A retired schoolteacher who bested the corporate bigs offers a lesson on how to turn anger into change.
link_name: Richmond Confidential: What It Takes to Beat the Elite

status_message:
"We need third parties in this country. And by that I don't mean another third party supported by billionaires, that centrist, you know, in the sort of Ross Perot manner. I mean parties that represent different opinions on the spectrum in the manner of the populist party in the 1890s which was really the last time we saw a third party movement, that contested the ballot from the bottom all the way to the top and they were a real political party. 

Unfortunately the techniques that the populists used are against the law in most states. If we were to repeal those laws you might have a vibrant third party scene again." - Thomas Frank, author of the new book "Listen Liberal" in a 2012 conversation with Bill Moyers.
link_name: Thomas Frank on Money in Politics

status_message: Many commentators said that terminating the controversial program would lead to a surge in crime, but the data tell a different story.
link_name: Ending New York's Stop-and-Frisk Did Not Increase Crime

status_message:
A preacher and two real estate entrepreneurs offer a glimpse of how far Ted Cruz could go in rolling back LGBT protections.

"Harris' and the Benhams' state activism is significant because, if Cruz wins the presidential race, the considerable influence of these three religious activists could extend far beyond North Carolina."
link_name: The Little-Known Movers Behind North Carolina's Anti-Gay Law: Ted Cruz's Advisers

status_message:
"Legislation is enacted under pressure," argued A. Philip Randolph, the labor leader and civil rights pioneer who had first called for a March on Washington in 1941, when he was advocating for the integration of defense industries. "You can't move senators and congressmen just because a measure is right. There must be pressure." 

Randolph was born on this day in 1889. Here, The Nation's John Nichols writes about Randolph's remarkable contributions -- and how his visionary "Freedom Budget For All Americans" document read like excerpts from a speech by U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders."
link_name: A. Philip Randolph Was Right: 'We Will Need To Continue Demonstrations'

status_message:
Brooklyn donnybrook –> This election, Democratic debates largely have been characterized by a respectful if strained cordiality between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. That collegiality slipped away at last night's debate in Brooklyn. 

"The highly contentious and spirited debate at the Brooklyn Navy Yard turned into an old-fashioned donnybrook with each candidate going after the other aggressively as they jockeyed for positioning just days before the state's April 19 primary," writes Adam Edelman for The New York Daily News. At The Guardian, Tom McCarthy provides a roundup of things we learned about the candidates, and, at Rolling Stone Magazine, Tessa Stuart managed to come up with a list of the "34 testiest moments."
link_name: Morning Reads: Democratic Debate in Brooklyn Turns Sour; 41% of Super PAC Money Comes from 50 People

status_message: Here are some of Sherman Alexie's favorite Native-American poets, with samplings of their work. #PoetryMonth
link_name: Sherman Alexie's Top Ten Native American Poets

status_message:
Eddie Lee Holloway Jr. spent $200, visited two states, and made seven trips to different public institutions, but still couldn't vote in Wisconsin.

Three hundred thousand registered voters in Wisconsin lack a government-issued photo ID, and many have faced great difficulty obtaining one.
link_name: A Black Man Brought 3 Forms of ID to the Polls in Wisconsin. He Still Couldn't Vote.

status_message: Investigative reporter David Cay Johnston on how legislation can work without even passing, which just happened when Pfizer's attempt to offshore its profits got stymied.
link_name: Beating Tax Inversions and Congressional Gridlock

status_message: NAACP President Cornell William Brooks, which has led the organization since 2014, talks to us about the connection between voting rights and campaign finance reform.
link_name: Why the NAACP Cares About Campaign Cash

status_message: As much as President Bill Clinton and President Obama like to talk about "free trade" deals, the truth is that the working class ends up paying.
link_name: Panama Papers Remind How Trade Deals Miss Sweet Spot

status_message: How many of you listen to podcasts? We've been doing some audio interviews and conversations here at BillMoyers.com and were thinking they would make a nice podcast offering. Some will feature conversations with Bill and others with journalists and experts we admire. Let us know if you would listen!  We're curious to hear your thoughts.

New York debate –> Democrats Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders face off at the Brooklyn Navy Yard tonight. Clinton, former US senator from the state, leads the polls, but native New Yorker Sanders has been drawing big crowds to his rallies, including an estimated 27,000 last night in Manhattan's Washington Square Park. At The New York Times, Alexander Burns offers some things to watch for. CNN coverage begins at 9 pm, ET.
link_name: Morning Reads: Democrats Debate in Brooklyn Tonight; Fed Says Big Banks Still Too Big

status_message: Fires, once largely confined to a single season, have become a continual threat in some places, burning earlier and later in the year, in the United States and abroad. They have ignited in the West during the winter and well into the fall, have arrived earlier than ever in Canada and have burned without interruption in Australia for almost 12 months, writes The New York Times.
link_name: Wildfires, Once Confined to a Season, Burn Earlier and Longer

status_message:
The political march is a tool for social transformation in itself. This one gave me a taste of the connected, empowered society I'm working to create, writes Frances Moore Lappé, cofounder of Small Planet Institute. 

Lappé is one of 400 protesters arrested outside of the United States Capitol on Monday from Democracy Spring, an organization working to get big money out of politics and fight restrictive voter ID laws.
link_name: What I Learned From My March With Democracy Spring

status_message:
The right to a lawyer doesn't count for much if nobody's willing to pay for it.

"I think where we would be violating the Constitution and ethics and professional standards would be to continue to take on cases we don't have the resources to handle." -- chief public defender Derwyn Bunton. His office began turning away clients after another round of budget cuts in January.
link_name: These New Orleans Public Defenders Actually Want to Get Sued

status_message: "I've been practicing tax law for 40 years. I've never seen anything quite like what is going on right now," said Owens, former director of the IRS division that regulated nonprofit institutions.
link_name: Former IRS Official Sees Dark Money Scandal Brewing

status_message: The industry-funded Competitive Enterprise Institute, with its long history of promoting inaccurate science and policies to discredit climate change, is now caught up in the "Exxon Knew" scandal.
link_name: Climate Denying Think Tank With Ties to Exxon Gets Subpoenaed

status_message:
House Speaker Paul Ryan wants you to know: He's not running for president. So he requests that you please stop saying he is. 

"Count me out: I simply believe that if you want to be the nominee for our party to be the president, you should actually run for it," he said yesterday. "I chose not to do this, therefore I should not be considered, period, end of story."

Now, how many of you believe him? Read more at the link below...
link_name: Morning Reads: Paul Ryan Says He's Not Running For President, Asks to Be Left Alone

status_message:
Dear Wall Street: Stop complaining about your pay, writes Bloomberg. 

"Five years after Occupy Wall Street protesters took over Zuccotti Park in downtown Manhattan, spawning a national discussion about the divide between America's highest and lowest earners, the pay gap has only gotten wider. Now, even as bankers bemoan their declining bonuses and job prospects, it's helping fuel the campaigns of Donald J. Trump and Bernie Sanders."
link_name: Wall Street Wages Double in 25 Years as Everyone Else's Languish

status_message: Bill Moyers, an 11-year-old at the time of Franklin D. Roosevelt's death, reflects on his father's reaction to the news on this day 71 years ago.
link_name: Bill Moyers Remembers the Day FDR Died

status_message:
Cultural scholar Stephanie Koontz talked to us about the realities behind the rhetoric of women balancing work and life.

"[Some states have initiated policies to help subsidize leave, so that it doesn't become a class privilege to stay home with your child. But I don't know of many politicians who have gotten very serious about it...  

A few years ago I would've said it's a Neanderthal approach, except that since then I've done enough research on prehistoric societies to conclude that Neanderthals took better care of their dependents than we do." #EqualPayDay
link_name: Is the 'War on Mothers' Really A War on Working-Class America?

status_message:
The potential for a depression looms on the horizon. Bernie Sanders is the only candidate who can stop banks from spiraling out of control again, writes Asher Edelman, an economist who spent more than 20 years on Wall Street. 

"Hillary Clinton is beholden to the banks for their largesse in funding her campaign and lining her pockets. The likelihood of any Republican candidate taking on this key issue is not even worthy of discussion."
link_name: I'm the real-life Gordon Gekko. But I support Bernie Sanders

status_message: Today is #EqualPayDay -- the date that symbolizes how far into the year women must work to earn what men earned in the previous year.
link_name: Debunking the Myth of a Mythical Gender Pay Gap

status_message: Democracy Spring hits DC –> More than 3,600 demonstrators protested on Capitol Hill yesterday, demanding an end to the conservative assault on voting rights and limits on the influence of money in politics. Some 400 were arrested. The demonstrations will continue through the weekend, part of the Democracy Spring movement. Alex Gangitano reports for Roll Call.
link_name: Morning Reads: Thousands Protest in DC for Campaign Finance Reform, Voting Rights

status_message: Newspapers in California published pro-TPP columns that appear to have been at least partially authored by lobbyists working for the Japanese government.
link_name: Pro-TPP Op-Eds Remarkably Similar to Drafts By Foreign Government Lobbyists

status_message: Amiri Baraka was "a poet and playwright of pulsating rage, whose long illumination of the black experience in America was called incandescent in some quarters and incendiary in others," said The New York Times in his obituary. In 1999 he was profiled by Bill Moyers as part of the series, "Sounds of Poetry." #PoetryMonth
link_name: Poet Amiri Baraka

status_message:
At the debates on Thursday between Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, will there be more discussion about political money and special interests?

Public Citizen criticizes the debate questioners. In the 21 debates, so far they asked about political money in 15 of more than 1,000 questions. The analysis found no questions on candidates' views of the system or ways they would change it.
link_name: TV Debates Light On Political Money Talk

status_message: Two leaders of organizations endorsing this week's demonstrations in Washington argue that campaign finance and voting rights are issues of morality.
link_name: Why Campaign Finance, Voting Rights Are Religious Issues

status_message: Pfizer, the giant drug company best known for Viagra, got smacked down last week for its snarky plan to save $35 billion in US taxes by becoming Irish. The Treasury Department is often a limp watchdog when it comes to policing arcane tax dodges, but this time, Treasury grew some fangs by tightening its regulations, which led Pfizer to call off the deal, writes William Greider.
link_name: Capitalist Deserter Pfizer Just Got a Spanking

status_message:
"In a bid to shift the ideological makeup of the Wisconsin's high court, dark money groups poured more than $2 million into the race. They put their financial muscle behind state Supreme Court Justice Rebecca Bradley who went on to beat Wisconsin Court of Appeals Judge JoAnne Cloppenburg ...

"Outside spending has soared in the years since the Citizens United ruling, and conservative political networks are targeting the courts in states where judges are elected in the hopes of adding more conservative judges. Much of that outside spending comes from nonprofit groups that don't have to disclose their donors," writes The American Prospect.
link_name: Dark Money Was the Real Winner in Wisconsin

status_message: Waterboarding will not resume –> "CIA Director John Brennan told NBC News in an exclusive interview that his agency will not engage in harsh "enhanced interrogation" practices, including waterboarding, which critics call torture — even if ordered to by a future president. 'I will not agree to carry out some of these tactics and techniques I've heard bandied about because this institution needs to endure,' Brennan said."
link_name: Morning Reads: CIA Head Says He'd Refuse Order to Torture; Wisconsin's Anti-Union Law Struck Down

status_message: What would it be like if voters made decisions based on actual facts rather than their assumptions? Rick Shenkman, founder of History News Network, takes on this question in "Political Animals: How Our Stone-Age Brain Gets in the Way of Smart Politics."
link_name: For Voters, Facts Should Be the Lifeblood of Democracy - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
"I had a conversation with a progressive senator who is not a fan of super PACs and at the time did not have his own sort of individual super PAC… 

And I said, 'What is this like when you're going to go up against an opponent who does have a super PAC and does have a motivated one percenter in his corner?' And he said, 'It's like going into a boxing ring. I'm wearing boxing gloves. And the other guy has an Uzi." -- Journalist, Andy Kroll
link_name: Clip: What You Need to Know About Dark Money | BillMoyers.com

status_message:
It's the elites vs the people in this presidential campaign, and nothing less than democracy is at stake. 

"When Paul Ryan talks about 'makers and takers,' National Review denigrates minorities and poor whites, and Republican legislatures suppress the vote, they are echoing the ideas, the language, and the actions of Civil War-era slave owners," writes Salon.
link_name: This war is for America's soul: Donald Trump, Paul Ryan and how wealthy white elites protect...

status_message:
This week, a GOP congressman from Wisconsin said a new voter ID law will help the eventual Republican presidential nominee win the state in November, writes The Huffington Post. 

Rep. Glenn Grothman's prediction gave credence to critics of voter ID laws who say they are tools used by conservatives to disenfranchise the poor and minorities, many of whom vote for Democrats. He told a reporter that despite past GOP candidates' poor showings in the Badger State, this year will be different. 'Now we have photo ID, and I think photo ID is gonna make a little bit of a difference as well,' he said.
link_name: Wisconsin Congressman Admits Voter ID Law Will Help GOP Nominee Win

status_message:
The White House announced a number of controversial business-related decisions, including a change in tax policy, this week. 

"The rule, issued by the Treasury Department, aims to make it harder for American companies to reduce their taxes by purchasing or merging with smaller foreign firms, a move known as a "corporate inversion." It bore fruit immediately, forcing the US pharmaceutical giant Pfizer on Wednesday to call off its $160 billion merger with the Dublin-based Botox-maker Allergen."

Also, the Labor Department finalized a rule that requires brokers selling retirement investments to put the client's interest ahead of their own.
link_name: Obama moves to agitate big business

status_message:
"Whether retail customers actually buy all these screeds, or whether foundations and rich conservative donors buy them in bulk and give them out as door prizes at right-wing clambakes, anti-knowledge infects the political bloodstream in the United States.

Thanks to these overlapping and mutually reinforcing segments of the right-wing media-entertainment-"educational" complex, it is now possible for the true believer to sail on an ocean of political, historical, and scientific disinformation without ever sighting the dry land of empirical fact." -- Mike Lofgren
link_name: The GOP and the Rise of Anti-Knowledge

status_message:
Remember Charles Keating? In a blast from the past, we found this show from 1992, in which Bill Moyers examines the effect of political contributions on public policy.

From Bill's 1992 intro: "The influence of money is why millions of Americans have abandoned the political process. They see that Washington has become a mercenary culture where the vote doesn't matter as much as the dollar. Public policy is determined more by campaign contributions than by merit, debate or deliberation..."
link_name: Who Owns Our Government?

status_message: The pathway is cleared for 21 kids to take the Obama administration to court over US climate policies.
link_name: Kids Clear Key Hurdle in Their Federal Climate Change Lawsuit

status_message:
This week, the Supreme Court declined to hear appeals by Walmart and Wells Fargo in moves that upheld two class action judgments that went against the multinational giants.

"Walmart had been ordered to pay $150 million to 187,000 Pennsylvania workers for wage theft that occurred between 1998-2006... and Wells Fargo had been ordered by a federal appellate judge in 2014 to pay California consumers $203 million, for misleading them on overdraft policies in violation of state consumer protection laws," writes Truthout.
link_name: Two Losses for Bosses: SCOTUS Rules Against Walmart, Wells Fargo in Class-Action Suits

status_message: ProPublica's Dollars for Docs database contains payments to doctors and teaching hospitals from pharmaceutical and medical device companies made between August 2013 and December 2014 -- totaling $3.5 billion. You can enter your doctor's name to see if he or she has received payment. Some 684,915 of America's doctors have.
link_name: Dollars for Docs

status_message: Delaware is home to more than a million companies, meaning it has more companies than actual human residents.
link_name: Why Are There so Many Anonymous Corporations in Delaware?

status_message:
Bruce Springsteen announced today that he is canceling his performance in North Carolina this weekend because of the organized assault by the state legislature against human rights.

Bill Moyers writes that "some of you may not be aware of what has been happening there since right-wing Republicans, led by the billionaire businessman Art Pope, effectively bought the political system with campaign contributions and 'dark money,' some of it traced to GOP organizations in Washington."

"The takeover of the state and the makeover of its once progressive institutions is one of the revealing and chilling stories of modern politics, one that along with Wisconsin lays bare the heart of the Republican strategy for America." 

Watch it and you will understand the backstory that led to Bruce Springsteen's announcement today: http://billmoyers.com/episode/state-of-conflict-north-carolina
link_name: A Note From Bill Moyers - Why The Boss Won't Play North Carolina

status_message: "As the media have fired their blunderbusses at Donald J. Trump, trying to take down his candidacy — even as they benefit from the attention he brings them — you may have missed the whacks they've been taking at Hillary Clinton. She has been the media's national piñata for so long, and the criticisms of her are so familiar by now, they are embedded in our consciousness as presumptions of guilt," writes Neal Gabler.
link_name: The Media Have a Hillary Story and They're Sticking to It

status_message:
Bill Moyers recommends Thomas Frank's new book "Listen Liberal." 

"Frank's thesis is that today's Democratic 'liberalism' is nothing like that of Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman or Lyndon B. Johnson. As Frank sees it, their crusade for 'Molly and the babies' (as LBJ called his working-class constituents) has been supplanted by a crusade — by Barack Obama, the Clintons, by Rahm Emanuel, by Larry Summers, by Deval Patrick — to advance the interests of well-off, well-educated, well-credentialed elites who sport Ivy League degrees, high net worths and vacation houses on Martha's Vineyard."
link_name: Thomas Frank's New Book Is "Thought-Provoking--and Guilt-Inducing"

status_message: Democratic lawmakers have declared that they will work to get money out of politics, but only a few are interested in getting rid of a Democratic Party system that allows corporate lobbyists to select the party's presidential nominee, potentially thwarting the will of voters, writes The Intercept's Lee Fang.
link_name: Some Democratic Lawmakers Are Open to Removing Lobbyists as Superdelegates

status_message: New York values –> The remaining presidential candidates are all campaigning hard to win New York State's many delegates on April 19. With both races still competitive at this late stage, NY is far more important than usual. Visits to New York City by the candidates inevitably lead to a slew of headlines like this one, from Bloomberg: "Presidential Candidates Brandish New York City Credentials With Matzah, Italian Food and Turnstiles."
link_name: Morning Reads: Candidates Burnish Their New York Values

status_message:
"There are two Democrats whose resignation from office right now would do their party and country a service. 

Their disappearance might also help Hillary Clinton convince skeptical Democrats that her nomination, if it happens, is about the future, and not about resurrecting and ratifying the worst aspects of the first Clinton reign when she and her husband rarely met a donor to whom they wouldn't try to auction a sleepover in the Lincoln Bedroom."

                                                           - Bill Moyers and Michael Winship

Please LIKE and SHARE if you agree!
link_name: Time for These Two Democrats to Go

status_message: How the United States became a prisoner of war and Congress went MIA.
link_name: Writing a Blank Check on War for the President - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Despite challenges, activist Saru Jayaraman believes she can overcome "even the most hardened, moneyed lobbyists in Washington, DC." In this clip, she tells Bill why she continues to fight for a living wage for tipped workers.

In a separate essay at BillMoyers.com, Jayaraman notes that this month marks the 25th year that the minimum wage for restaurant workers -- waiters, bussers, bartenders and kitchen staff -- has been frozen at an abysmal $2.13 per hour.

Share this video and her essay -- http://bit.ly/23frdln -- if you think tipped workers deserve a raise. 

Watch Bill's entire interview with Saru Jayaraman: http://billmoyers.com/episode/all-work-and-no-pay
link_name: Saru Jayaraman on Fighting the Powers That Be in Washington

status_message:
Since the creation of the minimum wage almost a century ago, federal law has mandated that tipped workers be paid less than everyone else, a practice rooted in American slavery, when employers didn't want to pay newly freed slaves a wage. 

Why? Because of the undue and enduring influence of our friends at the National Restaurant Association (NRA)...
link_name: It's Been 25 Years Since Restaurant Workers Got a Raise - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Stephen Colbert's campaign finance lawyer (remember his super PAC?) thinks Donald J. Trump, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders should join forces on getting money out of politics. And he's not kidding.
link_name: Trevor Potter: Happy Campaign Finance Warrior - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Slouching towards action –> Brett Wolf at Reuters: "The U.S. Treasury Department intends to soon issue a long-delayed rule forcing banks to seek the identities of people behind shell-company account holders, after the 'Panama Papers' leak provoked a global uproar over the hiding of wealth via offshore banking devices. A department spokesman said on Wednesday the rule would 'soon' be turned over to the White House for review and issuance, but did not confirm any timetable for the initiative, which has taken years."
link_name: Morning Reads: The Panama Papers May Lead to New Banking Rule - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
"My father was a machinist at a steel factory for 29 years. A white male who wore a hard hat to work, carried his lunch in a pail and washed his dark blue uniform at the end of every day, the metallic and earthy smell lingering in the laundry room. 

He was America's hero, part of the brawny working class who soldered, heaved and secured America's industrial might in the world, earning the pride and respect of our nation. That working class is dead, Detroit's bankruptcy providing a blunt symbol of its demise..." -- Tamara Draut, author of the new book, "Sleeping Giant: How the New Working Class Will Transform America."
link_name: America's New Working Class Demands Respect - BillMoyers.com

status_message: The risk of lead poisoning isn't just in Flint. Here's a map of the risk of every neighborhood in America.
link_name: Where is the lead exposure risk in your community?

status_message: Ordinary people in California and across the country have invested their time and talent toward the goal of lifting working families out of poverty -- and the movement is gaining momentum. And the fight could be coming to your state soon.
link_name: How the Fight for 15 Won - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Students waited hours to vote and longtime voters were turned away by the state's new photo ID law, writes The Nation's Ari Berman.
link_name: Wisconsin's Voter ID Law Caused Major Problems at the Polls Last Night

status_message: Here's a strong but fair piece from the heart on the media establishment in DC by CNN's Jeff Greenfield, whose long experience in politics and journalism began with Robert F. Kennedy back in the 60s.
link_name: What's Wrong With Hillary?

status_message: Wisconsin decides –> "The frontrunners fell on both sides in Wisconsin's presidential primary Tuesday, injecting new intrigue, chaos and drama into an epic campaign," Craig Gilbert writes at the Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel. Each had a double-digit win, and Bernie Sanders' was his sixth in a row. For his part, Ted Cruz succeeded in making the possibility of an open Republican convention more likely. The next big state to vote is New York on April 19.
link_name: Morning Reads: Sanders, Cruz Win Wisconsin by Double Digits - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
The 'Panama Papers' story blasted out to the world on Sunday afternoon: an amazing windfall of data — more than 11.5 million documents — the property of a Panamanian law firm that specializes in offshore tax havens, had been leaked. 

Over 400 reporters from 100 media organizations have been analyzing the documents over the past year, and uncovered a vast labyrinth of shady financial dealings linking back to Vladimir Putin; professional soccer, Bollywood and Jackie Chan, to name a few.  The prime minister of Iceland has already resigned and there's still more to come.
link_name: The Panama Papers: What They're All About - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Bill Bishop, author of The Big Sort, thinks there's more than financial angst behind today's politics.

"Voters are angry, we're told. They're ticked off at immigrants and terrorists and student loans, yes, but mostly they are angry with the people in charge. Crazy angry. The guy fixing an appliance at my house the other day said he doubted our "tyrannical" president would leave office peacefully. So he was laying in supplies — food and water, just like in the bomb shelter days — because there was a conflict sure to come..."
link_name: Why Do the Voters Rage? - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Are the crowds that cheer on Donald J. Trump a rabble or the architects of democracy? 

"Trump is the outcome of a long process which has weakened institutions where people from diverse backgrounds once interacted: civic associations, neighborhood schools, union groups and locally oriented businesses."
link_name: "We the People" in the Era of Trump - BillMoyers.com

status_message: On Last Week Tonight with John Oliver, the show's host eviscerated Congress for members' endless hard money fundraising — a member of Congress actually referred to it as torture. You can watch the whole clip here (it's long, but absolutely worth it).
link_name: Money in Politics is a Crisis—And John Oliver Just Proved It - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
One of the country's toughest voting restrictions takes effect for the April 5 primary today -- and could keep 9 percent of Wisconsin voters from the polls. 

"Some of the these include a man born in a concentration camp in Germany who lost his birth certificate in a fire; a woman who lost use of her hands but could not use her daughter as power of attorney at the DMV; and a 90-year-old veteran of Iwo Jima who could not vote with his veterans ID," writes The Nation's Ari Berman.
link_name: Wisconsin's Voter-ID Law Could Block 300,000 Registered Voters From the Polls - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Conservative challenge to voting law "fizzles" –> "For the second time in two weeks, a conservative bid to shift the law to the right fizzled at the Supreme Court, when the justices on Monday upheld the current, widely-used method of counting every person—not just voters—when drawing election districts," David Savage writes for the Los Angeles Times. Had the suit prevailed, districts with large numbers of children or immigrants would have less of a voice.
link_name: Morning Reads: Unanimous Supreme Court Blocks Bid to Change How States Count Voters - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Bernie Sanders believes that the repeal of Glass-Steagall in 1999 led to the formation of banks that became "too big to fail" -- and will lead to another crisis without corrective legislation. 

In this post, the History Channel's Edward Morris explains how Glass–Steagall Legislation came to be in 1933, despite J.P. Morgan's protestations, it's repeal in 1999 and why Bernie Sanders has the right idea.
link_name: Why Bernie's Right About Glass-Steagall - BillMoyers.com

status_message: In a rare show of unanimity, the justices stand behind the concept of one person, one vote.
link_name: Why Monday's Supreme Court Decision on Redistricting Is Important

status_message: Progressives need to fight back with their own "meta-narrative" against the tall tales of the right wing.
link_name: The Kochs Are Ghostwriting America's Story

status_message:
A new report examines the costs and burdens transgender citizens face in trying to comply with photo ID voter laws, writes The Atlantic's CityLab. 

"It may be difficult and costly for a transgender person to obtain photo identification that accurately reflects their gender and appearance after they have transitioned. Updating forms of ID with a change of gender is a unique responsibility that transgender people bear in order to vote in strict photo ID states. The processes involved in updating IDs have costs that impose disparate burdens on transgender Americans who wish to vote in these states. These costs are significant."
link_name: How ID Laws Disenfranchise Transgender Voters

status_message: Meet some of the people who are now walking from Philadelphia to Washington, DC, to protest money in politics, an issue that has been getting more attention this election season.
link_name: Money-in-Politics Protesters Kick Off March From Philadelphia to DC - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
A massive trove of documents leaked this weekend from a Panamanian law firm connects more than 70 current and former world leaders to offshore tax havens used to secretly hoard billions. Vladimir Putin plays a central role, reports Luke Harding for The Guardian: 

"Though the president's name does not appear in any of the records, the data reveals a pattern – his friends have earned millions from deals that seemingly could not have been secured without his patronage. 

"The documents suggest Putin's family has benefited from this money – his friends' fortunes appear his to spend. The files are part of an unprecedented leak of millions of papers from the database of Mossack Fonseca, the world's fourth biggest offshore law firm. They show how the rich and powerful are able to exploit secret offshore tax regimes in myriad ways."
link_name: Morning Reads: Document Trove Reveals International Web of Corruption; NY Poised to Raise Min. Wage

status_message:
After the Supreme Court upheld Texas' harsh voter ID law in 2014, Bill spoke with Sherrilyn Ifill, president and director-counsel of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, a noted civil rights litigator whose work has included landmark voting rights cases. She told Bill, "The right to vote was sacrosanct because it was the thing that came with your citizenship. It was the great equalizer. And we're seeing a different philosophy about the meaning of that exercise of citizenship."

The Nation Magazine's Ari Berman joined her, "We have a Supreme Court that wants to make it easier for millionaires to buy an election, but harder for everyday people to vote in one. And that's a very, very disturbing reality right now."
link_name: The Fight — and the Right — to Vote | Moyers & Company

status_message:
Ian Haney López highlights six political ads from the last three decades that used racially coded language to help a candidate get elected. 

This includes one of the most famous cases of political dog whistling -- when North Carolina Republican Senator Jesse Helms campaigned against Democratic opponent Harvey Gantt's support of affirmative action in hiring, which Helms derided as racial "quotas." You can watch the 1990 "Hands" ad here.
link_name: Six Case Studies in Dog Whistle Politics

status_message:
The Revival: Time for A Moral Revolution of Values, led by the Rev. Dr. William J. Barber II and the Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes, Jr., aims to be the catalyst for a resurgence of moral political activism among people of conscience and faith leaders.

The two pastor/scholars have been invited to 15 states for the first leg of the tour. Joining the pastors in selected sites will be faith leaders the Rev. Traci Blackmon and Sister Simone Campbell.

The tour will kick off in New York, New York on Sunday at 3 pm. You can watch the lifestream here.
link_name: Revival Tour Launch LiveStream from New York City

status_message: John Fetterman has been mayor of the hardscrabble Pittsburgh suburb of Braddock for over a decade. His tattoos (of the town's zip code and the dates of its most recent murders) and his stature (nearly 7 feet) have drawn more attention than his politics. Despite being an under-funded, underdog, and drawing inspiration from Bernie Sanders, he is now running for a seat in the United States Senate.
link_name: Meet the Rust-Belt Populist Who Wants to Be Pennsylvania's Next Senator

status_message:
What do the candidates need to keep in mind if they hope to appeal to women across the board?

PBS NewsHour's Judy Woodruff explores how women see the presidential candidates with Rebecca Traister, author, "All the Single Ladies," Ann Selzer of Selzer & Company and Kelly Dittmar of the Center for American Women and Politics.
link_name: What the 'women's vote' means in 2016

status_message:
This week, a group of state attorneys general just declared war on big polluters, writes Think Progress. 

"The group, representing 17 states, said it will pursue climate change litigation. Massachusetts and the US Virgin Islands officially joined an ongoing investigation into potential fraud by ExxonMobil, and all the states committed to working together as 'creatively, collaboratively, and aggressively' as possible to combat climate change."
link_name: State AGs Vow To Tackle Climate Change And Fossil Fuel Industry Fraud

status_message: "Millions of workers across the country have won wage hikes under the banner of $15, and this week many more in California stand poised to join the parade. But three and a half years after the first picket sign was hoisted demanding $15/hour and union recognition, very few minimum wage workers are actually getting paid that much. That's because among those crafting wage legislation, it's become an axiom that increases must be phased in over time for the sake of business and economic stability."
link_name: Most Americans Won't Make $15 an Hour for Five Years—but Why Not Now, Like in This City?

status_message: On the left and the right, any trust in authorities and institutions — science, the church, the party — is considered a pathetic kind of naiveté.
link_name: billmoyers.com

status_message:
This week, U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren announced a plan for the US Department of Education (DOE) to completely overhaul its student loan servicing system. 

Earlier this month, the Democrat from Massachusetts roundly condemned the DOE for putting the desires of the student loan industry over the needs of students, referring to a scandal in which the DOE protected one of the country's largest loan companies (Navient, formerly known as Sallie Mae) from repercussions for defrauding U.S. service members.
link_name: Elizabeth Warren Calls for Total Overhaul of Student Loan System

status_message:
Every single county in the US lacks affordable housing, and in no state can someone earning a minimum wage salary rent a two-bedroom apartment at market rate, according to a new report by the National Low Income Housing Coalition. 

The reports finds that there is a shortage of 7.2 million affordable and available rental units for America's 10.4 million extremely low income renter households.
link_name: Mapping the Appalling Affordable Housing Deficit for Each State in the US

status_message:
This week, Maricopa County, Arizona elections officials came under heavy pressure by state legislators and voters to explain why thousands of voters waited for hours to cast ballots in the state's most populous county, writes Mother Jones. 

"The special hearing to address the issue turned contentious as state representatives and angry voters lobbed accusations of voter suppression and discrimination by local elections officials."
link_name: Arizona voters are freaking out over their election mess

status_message:
While hanging chads and butterfly ballots grabbed the headlines during the chaotic 36-day Florida recount in Bush v Gore in 2000, the most consequential — and least discussed — aspect of the Florida election was the widespread and wrongful purging of registered voters, writes Ari Berman. 

"Bush's election empowered a new generation of voting-rights critics, who hyped the threat of voter fraud in order to restrict access to the ballot, and remade a Supreme Court that would eventually gut the centerpiece of the Voting Rights Act.'
link_name: How the 2000 Election in Florida Led to a New Wave of Voter Disenfranchisement

status_message: A unique new partnership between local leaders and teachers strengthened a community and its school system, even after it was devastated by one of the worst tornadoes in United States history.
link_name: Joplin, Missouri's Bright Future

status_message: The tabloid story about anonymous allegations against Ted Cruz shows all too clearly how politics and media have become part of a show business machine fueled by gossip and snark.
link_name: Why the National Enquirer's Hot Air is Filling the MSM Balloon - BillMoyers.com

status_message: As of today, more than 500,000 Americans stand to lose their Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits, which reminded us of this CBS clip of Bill reporting on the effects of President Reagan's welfare cuts.  #flashbackfriday
link_name: How Did Reagan's Welfare Cuts Affect the Poor?

status_message: The 2016 presidential race is fraying the Washington consensus, exposing the downside of trade deals like the Trans-Pacific Partnership. It's time for a new way forward on trade, writes Patrick Woodall of Food & Water Watch.
link_name: The Changing Politics of Free Trade — Politicians are Finally Listening

status_message:
New polling by the Pew Research Center reveals that Republican and Democratic voters have different visions of the way that life in the United States has changed. 

"Overall, 46% of registered voters say that life in America today is worse than it was 50 years ago 'for people like them,' while 34% say life is better and 14% think it is about the same. Republican and Republican-leaning voters are more than twice as likely as Democratic voters to say life in this country has gotten worse over the past half-century for people like them (66% to 28%)."
link_name: Campaign Exposes Fissures Over Issues, Values and How Life Has Changed in the US

status_message: The Democratic Party's special class of entitled and unelected VIP delegates helps explain what's wrong with the way we choose our presidential candidates.
link_name: A Bird, A Plane? No, It's Superdelegates!

status_message:
Holding the line in the states –> "Establishment Republicans and their big-money allies are rushing to build a multistate defense system to protect Senate and House candidates, fearing that the party could lose its hold on Congress if Donald Trump is at the top of the ticket in November," Matea Gold and Paul Kane report at The Washington Post. 

"The behemoth Koch operation — which aims to spend almost $900 million before the November elections — is now considering abandoning Trump as a nominee and focusing its resources on behalf of GOP congressional candidates."
link_name: Morning Reads: Big Money Push to Help GOP Save Congress From Trump - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Over the course of 4 months, 97,100 metric tons of methane leaked out of a gas well into California's sky. Scientists and residents are still trying to figure out just how much damage was done, writes The New York Times. 

"During the four months the leak lasted... [it] contributed roughly the same amount of warming as the greenhouse-­gas emissions produced by the entire country of Lebanon." And as the Los Angeles Times reported on Monday, the top executive over SoCal Gas collected a $3.17 million bonus, bringing her total compensation for 2015 to $16.1 million.
link_name: The Invisible Catastrophe

status_message:
In reporting on some of the voting issues that have risen during the party primaries in New Hampshire, North Carolina and Arizona these past few months — namely waiting lines as long as five hours and confusing new voter ID rules — The Nation's Ari Berman often reminds his readers that the 2016 election is "the first in 50 years without the full protections of the Voting Rights Act."

In this audio conversation, authors Ari Berman and Michael Waldman talk about the unequal history of voting in America, new voting rules and their concerns about what may happen at the polls later this year.
link_name: Why There May Be Trouble This November at Your Polling Place

status_message: The number of Americans using alternate work arrangements rose 9.4 million from 2005 to 2015 -- shifting much the burden of providing social insurance onto workers, writes The New York Times
link_name: With 'Gigs' Instead of Jobs, Workers Bear New Burdens

status_message:
Starting tomorrow, at least half a million Americans will wake up no longer eligible for the food assistance benefits,  writes The Atlantic's CityLab. 

"A clause in the 1996 Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Act limited Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits to three months in any given 36-month period for unemployed adults between the ages of 18 and 49 who are not working or enrolled in a job-training or community service program at least 20 hours per week."
link_name: On April 1, SNAP Benefits Will Run Out for More Than 500,000 Unemployed Americans

status_message:
John Upton at Climate Central:

"The world's greatest reservoir of ice is verging on a breakdown that could push seas to heights not experienced since prehistoric times, drowning dense coastal neighborhoods during the decades ahead, new computer models have shown. 

A pair of researchers developed the models to help them understand high sea levels during previous eras of warmer temperatures. Then they ran simulations using those models and found that rising levels of greenhouse gases could trigger runaway Antarctic melting that alone could push sea levels up by more than three feet by century's end. 

The same models showed that Antarctica's ice sheet would remain largely intact if the most ambitious goals of last year's Paris agreement on climate change are achieved." Read more...
link_name: #MorningReads: A Crucial Tipping Point in Antarctica

status_message:
Arizona's Republican-controlled legislature voted Tuesday to dismantle the state's strict campaign-finance disclosure rules, a move critics say will unleash a flood of undisclosed political spending in an election already increasingly dominated by "dark" money.

The fight has pitted good government activists against deep-pocketed corporate donors and political groups underwritten by the billionaire industrialists Charles and David Koch, writes Justin Miller of The American Prospect.
link_name: Arizona Becomes Ground Zero in Fight Over Secret Political Spending

status_message:
At some point during the Florida 2000 recount debacle partisans realized anew that razor-thin margins can be turned by manipulation of voting rules, writes Michael Waldman of Brennan Center for Justice at NYU Law. 

Waldman describes "an energetic band of partisan activists who produced much of the noise [about allegations of voter fruad] many of them clustered around then Attorney General John Ashcroft. Here's one of several described in the post: 

"Bradley Schlozman, a 32-year-old lawyer, swept through the Voting Rights section of the Department's Civil Rights Division, ignoring hiring rules: he pushed out civil servants and tried to hire fellow members of the Federalist Society, the conservative legal network. A report by the department's independent inspector general revealed Schlozman's approach. 'I too get to work with mold spores,' he wrote to a colleague, 'but here in Civil Rights, we call them Voting Section attorneys.' He continued, 'My tentative plans are to gerrymander all of those crazy libs right out of the section.' Schlozman eventually became the acting chief of the Civil Rights Division."
link_name: What's Behind the GOP Witch Hunt for Voter Fraud

status_message:
The media has become controlled by a handful of corporations thanks to the Telecommunications Act of 1996. 

"This issue has not been central in the 2016 presidential election. But it is deeply concerning that, of all the presidential candidates running in 2016, the Big Media lobby has chosen to back Hillary Clinton," writes Michael Corcoran.
link_name: Twenty Years of Media Consolidation Has Not Been Good For Our Democracy

status_message: While California has reached a deal to raise its minimum wage to $15, lawmakers in other states are moving in the opposite direction.
link_name: States Move to Roll Back City Minimum-Wage Raises

status_message:
AGs get tough on polluters –> Yesterday, attorneys general from eighteen states and US territories pledged to work together investigating whether fossil fuel companies have misled investors about the threat of climate change and its impact on business. Massachusetts AG Maura Healey and Virgin Islands AG Claude Earl Walker also announced they would join an investigation of Exxon already underway by New York State Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, following reports by InsideClimate News and the Los Angeles Times that the company intentionally misled the public on climate science.

BuzzFeed's Dan Verano writes, "The 'AGs United for Clean Power' group are largely members of states that have supported the Obama Administration's clean power plan that would cut greenhouse gas emissions from power plants nationwide."
link_name: Morning Reads: State AGs Band Together to Crack Down on Polluters; Labor Wins Big at SCOTUS

status_message:
In his new book, "Listen Liberal" Thomas Frank writes about the Democrats' new innovation in liberalism -- which isn't the stuff of Franklin D. Roosevelt or the United Auto Workers.

"Innovation liberalism is 'a liberalism of the rich' ... This doctrine has no patience with the idea that everyone should share in society's wealth," writes Frank in this excerpt.
link_name: The Blue State Model

status_message: We do face a very real threat of protectionism, but Obama's the one pushing it.
link_name: Think Trump's 45 Percent Tariffs Are Bad? Try Obama's 10,000 Percent Tariffs

status_message: Marco money –> Shane Goldmacher at POLITICO: "Marco Rubio's campaign is dead. His secret-money legacy lives on. Nobody knows who funded the nonprofit group that spent more than $10 million on TV ads boosting Rubio, and untold more on mailers and research. And, unless those donors out themselves, nobody ever will. No presidential candidate fighting for their party's nomination has ever benefited from as much undisclosed cash, and watchdogs worry the pro-Rubio group's unchecked activity serves as a dangerous precedent that will soon become common practice."
link_name: Morning Reads: Marco Rubio Changed the World of Dark Money - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
In Michigan, a proposal -- pushed by the state's utility companies -- to reduce payments to solar consumers could scare off people who are considering investing in solar energy, writes The American Prospect. 

"The regulatory overhaul, which mirrors changes being considered in states nationwide, would slash payments for solar consumers who sell excess energy back to utility companies while also significantly weakening the state's clean-energy mandates. With federal energy policymaking at a standstill, this controversy once again puts Michigan at the center of the nationwide debate over state-level climate policy."
link_name: Michigan Energy Policy Overhaul Pits Power Companies Against Solar Advocates

status_message:
After years of discussing how to age well, a group of retired people is building the first French residential co-op for seniors.

"Seven years after their first discussions about how to age well, a group of retired people is starting to build the first co-op for the aging. Non-speculation, democracy and environmental concern are the foundations of the "Chamarel-Les Barges" project, located in a neighborhood of Vaulx-en-Velin, east of Lyon, France. The project is so inspiring that the bank has even conferred a 50-year loan to the founders, who are in their 60s," writes Truthout.
link_name: In France, a Retirement Co-op Ensures Seniors Are Not Treated as Commodities

status_message: America has moved into a world that defies historical comparisons — and we can't blame it all on Donald Trump, writes Tom Engelhardt
link_name: Entering Uncharted Territory in Washington

status_message:
Thanks to Citizens United, LLCs are able to make contributions to super PACs without disclosing donors -- and their use is on the rise. 

Will Tucker of the Center for Responsive Politics highlights the use of these entities to circumvent campaign finance disclosure requirements.
link_name: LLC Gifts Are Making up a Bigger Share of Super PACs' Fundraising Hauls

status_message:
The Economist writes that US corporations are benefiting from a corrosive lack of competition.

"High profits can deepen inequality in various ways. The pool of income to be split among employees could be squeezed. Consumers might pay too much for goods. In a market the size of America's prices should be lower than in other industrialised economies. By and large, they are not. Though American companies now make a fifth of their profits abroad, their naughty secret is that their return-on-equity is 40% higher at home."
link_name: Too much of a good thing

status_message:
Time for a raise –> John Myers and Liam Dillon at the Los Angeles Times: "Lawmakers and labor unions have struck a tentative deal to raise the statewide minimum wage to $10.50 an hour next year and then gradually to $15, averting a costly political campaign this fall and possibly putting California at the forefront of a national movement." A voter initiative on the minimum wage had been scheduled for the November ballot.

AND: At Slate.com, Jordan Weissmann writes, "This would be a breathtaking victory for labor activists. While a handful of cities, including San Francisco and Los Angeles, have already enacted their own $15 minimum wage laws, no state has, according to the National Employment Law Project."
link_name: Morning Reads: California Will Soon Be First State With a $15 Minimum Wage - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
"Trump has, in his usual unvarnished manner, kicked open the door to an important and fundamental foreign-policy debate. 

It is far more profound than the disputes we usually hear between hawks and doves. He's proposing a radical standard for testing US policy abroad, both in war and peace," writes William Greider at The Nation.
link_name: Donald Trump Could Be the Military-Industrial Complex's Worst Nightmare

status_message: The US territory can't pay its debts and will soon run out of money. How did it get into this mess? The Week explains.
link_name: The Puerto Rico crisis, explained

status_message: Lawmakers and labor unions have struck a tentative deal to raise the statewide minimum wage to $10.50 an hour next year and then gradually to $15, averting a costly political campaign this fall and possibly putting California at the forefront of a national movement, writes the Los Angeles Times.
link_name: Deal reached to boost California's minimum wage to $15, avoiding ballot box battle

status_message:
A report released this week by a task force to study how Flint's drinking water became poisoned by lead makes for chilling reading, The New York Times reported this week. 

"Flint residents, who are majority black or African-American and among the most impoverished of any metropolitan area in the US, did not enjoy the same degree of protection from environmental and health hazards as that provided to other communities," the report said. 

Here, Art Reyes III, who grew up in Flint, Michigan, describes how his family initially flocked to the city, which in the 50s had one of the highest per capita incomes in the country. Decades later, they are protesting for Michigan Governor Rick Snyder's resignation.
link_name: I Grew Up in Flint. Here's Why Governor Snyder Must Resign.

status_message: Joseph Campbell was born 112 years ago today. In this clip from "The Power of Myth," the mythologist spoke with Bill about the common experience of God across cultures. Read the full transcript of the episode, which we recently transcribed for the web, in which the two discuss commonalities in every culture that create a need for God, and the symbolism of circles in life and literature.
link_name: Ep. 6: Joseph Campbell and the Power of Myth -- 'Masks of Eternity'

status_message: Thirteen years ago this week the US pre-emptively attacked Iraq. In this 2007 documentary (available for full viewing here), Bill Moyers and his team investigates big media's role as cheerleader in the clamor for war in the months preceding the March invasion. How did the mainstream press get it so wrong in the run-up to the Iraq War?
link_name: Buying the War: How Big Media Failed Us - BillMoyers.com

status_message: "According to one recent OECD survey, the United States ranked 29th out of 36 countries for 'work-life balance,' a comparison of hours worked versus hours devoted to leisureIn most cases, the brunt of this brutal load falls harder on women, who still do the bulk of housework and may find careers, particularly those with the most financial and personal rewards, impossible to sustain," writes The Atlantic.
link_name: What Can Be Done to Make American Life Less Draining?

status_message:
Middle East expert Juan Cole writes on Informed Comment that societies need to rethink their words, actions and intentions following episodes of terrorism. 

#1. "Stop calling Daesh "the Islamic State." They are manipulating you. They aren't a state and they aren't Islamic. If some fringe cult took over some villages in Mexico and called itself 'The Vatican,' then committed terrorism, would journalists blithely say on air 'Today, the Vatican killed 39 and injured 200 with a bomb belt'? People in the Middle East hate this small desert fringe, and they term it 'Daesh,' not 'Islamic.' They should know."
link_name: How Not to Talk About Muslims After a Fringe Terrorist Group Attacks

status_message: The mainstream and right-wing press are melting down as they fumble coverage of the uncontrollable GOP frontrunner, writes Neal Gabler.
link_name: Donald Trump Triggers a Media Civil War

status_message:
The Affordable Care Act/Obamacare turned six this week and experts weighed in on Politico. 

"The ACA is something of a policy Rorschach test, with people seeing different things in it depending on their political leanings. While the 20 million additional people covered is an historic achievement, the ACA hasn't remade the health care system in all the ways advocates may have hoped. At the same time, it also hasn't been the job-killing death spiral that critics would have you believe." --  Larry Levitt, Kaiser Family Foundation
link_name: The ACA at six: What have we learned?

status_message: The fire-breathing populist has drawn small donors and really, really big ones, including a quartet whose names are all variations on "Keep the Promise," writes Will Tucker of The Center for Public Integrity.
link_name: Big Money — If Not the GOP Establishment — Has Been With Ted Cruz From the Start

status_message:
Corinthian colleges, the predatory for-profit college chain that scammed it's students, has been ordered to pay $1.1 billion in a suit brought by California's attorney. 

Earlier this month, Sarah Jaffe reported for BillMoyers.com that many of the school's students remain crippled by debt after paying big money for worthless degrees. 

http://billmoyers.com/story/the-for-profit-college-scam-that-these-students-are-still-paying-for/
link_name: The For-Profit College Scam That These Students Are Still Paying For - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
An investigation by The New York Times raises questions about the league's concussion research and its relationship with the tobacco industry.

"Confidential data obtained by The Times shows that more than 100 diagnosed concussions were omitted from the studies — including some severe injuries to stars like quarterbacks Steve Young and Troy Aikman. The committee then calculated the rates of concussions using the incomplete data, making them appear less frequent than they actually were."
link_name: In N.F.L., Deeply Flawed Concussion Research and Ties to Big Tobacco

status_message: Colorado's efforts to become the first state to pass a public, universal health care system are facing stiff opposition from right-wing organizations, many of which are funded by or affiliated with brothers Charles and David Koch, writes Truthout.
link_name: Koch Brothers Attempt to Kill Single-Payer Health Care in Colorado

status_message: The Muslim vote –> Alan Rappeport at The New York Times: "Organizations like the Council on American-Islamic Relations, known as CAIR, the Islamic Circle of North America and the U.S. Council of Muslim Organizations are encouraging mosques to turn themselves into voter registration centers before the November election so that Muslims can make their voices heard at the polls. Registration drives are expected to ramp up significantly in June, during Ramadan, when attendance at Islamic centers peaks. 'The fear and apprehension in the American Muslim community has never been at this level,' said Ibrahim Hooper, a spokesman for CAIR."
link_name: Morning Reads: Dems Way Out West Caucus Saturday; Muslim Americans Organize Against Trump, Cruz

status_message: "Events since Desert Storm in 1991 suggest that the all-volunteer military has been more curse than blessing. Partially to blame: a new dynamic in modern American history, the creation of a massive military force that is not of the people, by the people, or for the people," writes William J. Astore , a retired lieutenant colonel (USAF).
link_name: A Force Unto Itself: A Military Leviathan Has Emerged as America's 51st and Most Powerful State...

status_message:
Our leaders thought fracking would save our climate. They were very wrong, writes Bill McKibben. 

"Global warming is, in the end, not about the noisy political battles here on the planet's surface. It actually happens in constant, silent interactions in the atmosphere, where the molecular structure of certain gases traps heat that would otherwise radiate back out to space. If you get the chemistry wrong, it doesn't matter how many landmark climate agreements you sign or how many speeches you give."
link_name: Global Warming's Terrifying New Chemistry - BillMoyers.com

status_message: A historian of pre-Nazi Germany sees some uncomfortable parallels in the Republican establishment's love/hate relationship with the billionaire.
link_name: Who's Afraid of Trump? The Same People Who Made Him

status_message:
In a shocking, unprecedented move, the North Carolina state legislature convened a special session late Wednesday in order to introduce and pass a sweeping anti-LGBT bill, HB-2, which overturns local ordinances protecting gay and transgender rights. Republican Governor Pat McCrory signed the bill into law later that night, writes CommonDreams.org. 

"Rather than expand nondiscrimination laws to protect all North Carolinians, the General Assembly instead spent $42,000 to rush through an extreme bill that undoes all local nondiscrimination laws and specifically excludes gay and transgender people from legal protections," --  ACLU of North Carolina.
link_name: North Carolina Makes Discrimination Mandatory with Most Anti-LGBT Law in the Nation

status_message: Feedback loop –> "Amid blowout warm temperatures in the Arctic this year, two new studies have amplified concerns about one of the wild cards of a warming planet — how quickly warming Arctic soils could become major contributors of greenhouse gases to the atmosphere, causing still greater warming," Chris Mooney writes for The Washington Post. As ice melts, plant matter long trapped within the ice deteriorates, releasing potent greenhouse gases into the atmosphere.
link_name: Morning Reads: A Rapidly Thawing Arctic Could Speed Up Climate Change - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
"Commentators repeat endlessly the mantra that Sanders's Nordic-style policies might sound nice, but they'd never work in the U.S. The upshot is that Sanders, and his supporters, are being treated a bit like children—good-hearted, but hopelessly naive. That's probably how Nordic people seem to many Americans, too...

This is what Americans fail to understand: My taxes in Finland were used to pay for top-notch services for me," writes Anu Partanen, who lived in Finland before moving the the US.
link_name: I moved to the US 7 years ago from Finland — here's what Americans don't understand about Nordic...

status_message:
The Internet has revolutionized the ways presidential candidates connect with potential voters. But what have the presidential candidates done in exchange to protect the network that's become essential to their efforts?

Not much, writes Tim Carr, senior director of strategy for Free Press.
link_name: If Presidential Candidates Love the Internet, They Need to Set It Free

status_message:
Reducing the number of polling places in Phoenix had catastrophic consequences in the March 22 primary, writes The Nation's Ari Berman.

"After the Supreme Court gutted the Voting Rights Act in 2013, Arizona could make election changes without federal oversight. The long lines in Maricopa County last night were the latest example of the disastrous consequences of that decision."
link_name: There Were Five-Hour Lines to Vote in Arizona Because the Supreme Court Gutted the Voting Rights Act

status_message:
America's top nutrition thinker, Marion Nestle, tried to unpack the most important food law. 

"I came away from this experience convinced that agricultural policy in our country is not only hazardous to public health and the environment, but also to American democracy," writes Marion Nestle.
link_name: The Farm Bill Drove Me Insane - BillMoyers.com

status_message: He starred in a TV reality show, but Donald Trump's ascent is based on two classic movie archetypes.
link_name: Trump's Presidential Campaign Is Straight Out of Hollywood - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Brussels –> Yesterday's terror attacks on the international airport in Brussels and the city's subway system allegedly were carried out by at least three men, two of whom died in the explosions. Prosecutors identified them as brothers Khalid and Brahim Bakraou. The third suspect remains at large. ISIS claimed responsibility for the bombings. Jason Burke at The Guardian writes that the attacks may have been retribution following the arrest in Brussels last week of Salah Abdeslam, the alleged mastermind of last November's attacks in Paris.

In response to the attacks, all of the presidential candidates spoke out. Ted Cruz's campaign issued a press release saying, "We need to empower law enforcement to patrol and secure Muslim neighborhoods before they become radicalized."
link_name: Morning Reads: Two Brussels Bombers Identified; Sanders and Clinton Split Tuesday Delegates

status_message:
The decades-long "War on Drugs" was a tool for the federal government to crack down on leftist protesters and "black people," a former Nixon White House adviser has admitted. 

John Ehrlichman, who served as counsel to former President Richard Nixon, explained the use of the controversial policy in a 1994 interview with writer Dan Baum, that he revisited in a new article for Harper's Magazine.
link_name: Nixon Aide Reportedly Admitted Drug War Was Meant To Target Black People

status_message: Mayor Rahm Emanuel and Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz represent everything wrong with the Democratic Party. Hillary Clinton should tell them to take a hike, writes Bill Moyers and Michael Winship.

status_message: After suspected terrorist attacks in Brussels Tuesday morning that killed at least two dozen people and wounded more than 100, American politicians took to social media and TV news programs to respond to the violence.
