status_message:
Morning Reads: At an AIPAC meeting, Hillary Clinton sought to reassure the influential, conservative-leaning group that if elected, her administration would not continue tensions that arose between President Obama and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Her speech, meant to position Clinton as a safe alternative to Trump, was well received by the crowd, although critics, including Clinton supporter Michelle Goldberg, accused the candidate of pandering.

Bernie Sanders did not attend but spoke on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict during a campaign appearance in Utah, arguing that both sides need to step up efforts to facilitate the peace process, with Israelis "pulling back settlements in the West Bank, just as Israel did in Gaza – once considered an unthinkable move on Israel's part." Sanders also said, "Those who advocate for stronger military involvement by the U.S. to oust [Syrian President Bashar] Assad from power have not paid close enough attention to history. That would simply prolong the war and increase the chaos in Syria, not end it."
link_name: Morning Reads: Bombings in Brussels; Candidates Speak Out on Israel - BillMoyers.com

status_message: The American people will be footing the bill — but, by and large, they haven't heard much about our country's planned trillion-dollar nuclear weapons upgrade.
link_name: The US is Set to Spend $1 Trillion Upgrading Nuclear Weapons

status_message: Seth Meyers dissected restrictive new voter identification laws that are apparently intended to keep Americans from participating in democracy, writes The Raw Story.
link_name: Seth Meyers slams GOP-backed voter ID laws: They're an 'insane overreaction to a nonexistent...

status_message:
While Trump's benefits from constant coverage, that coverage is also a lifeline to news outlets. 

"Mr. Trump riled up his fans against a recurring villain in his running campaign narrative and ensured the news was once again all about him. Fox News, the cable news ratings leader that is so often impugned as an arm of the Republican Party, got to ring a bell for journalistic independence. Ms. Kelly got the sort of support from the network that she has described as lacking from her colleague Bill O'Reilly; guaranteed big ratings to come; and got more fodder for the book she sold for many millions of dollars after the Trump feud began.

Newspapers and online news organizations got a click-worthy story line tailor-made for a fast read on the iPhone. And, finally, there were the viewers and the readers ..."
link_name: The Mutual Dependence of Donald Trump and the News Media

status_message: President Obama in Havana –> He's the first American chief executive to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge sailed in on a battleship in 1928. Dan Roberts at The Guardian reports, "As he arrived, Obama used a Cuban phrase meaning 'what's up?' when he tweeted: '¿Que bolá Cuba? Just touched down here, looking forward to meeting and hearing directly from the Cuban people.'"
link_name: Morning Reads: Obama Arrives in Cuba; Trump's Schtick Doesn't Play Well With Mormons, AIPAC

status_message:
Congratulations to poet and novelist Wendell Berry, who was  awarded the Ivan Sandrof Lifetime Achievement Award by the National Book Critics Circle. 

Berry sat down to speak with Bill in a rare television interview in 2013.
link_name: Wendell Berry, Poet & Prophet

status_message: It's virtually impossible to avoid dangerous chemicals, even in your own home, but there are a few simple steps you can take to limit your exposure to known toxins like lead, flame retardants and BPA.
link_name: How to Avoid Toxic Chemicals

status_message: In this clip from 2014, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Marilynne Robinson tells Bill that as a society we are stooping way too low in the way we treat and speak to one another.
link_name: Clip: Marilynne Robinson -- We're Acting Beneath Our Dignity and the Media Is Making it Worse

status_message:
This week, the 2016 World Happiness Report came out and the United States ranked 13th of all countries for its happiness level this year. 

"For the first time, it included a ranking of happiness inequality -- what might be called the well-being gap, rather than the income gap -- within different countries, and the U.S. came in at No. 85 of 157 countries, between Chile and Slovenia," according to the Washington Post.
link_name: This is how the U.S. stacks up against the world's happiest countries

status_message:
Five years after the start of Syria's tragedy, The Independent's Middle East correspondent Robert Fisk reflects on the major mistakes made by the West.   

"It's worth taking that embarrassing trip down memory lane to the early spring and summer of 2011. The US and French ambassadors visited Homs to sit amid tens of thousands of peaceful demonstrators calling for the overthrow of the Assad government. EU diplomats were telling the political opposition not to negotiate with Assad – a fatal mistake, since the advice was based on the false assumption that he was about to be overthrown – and journalists were gathering with rebels in eastern Aleppo for the inevitable march of liberation on Damascus.

The Assad regime, came the message from the Washington think-tanks and mountebank "experts", had reached – a cliché we should all beware of – the 'tipping point'."
link_name: How the West Got It Wrong as the Syrian Civil War Developed

status_message: In this clip, media scholar Marty Kaplan says American news media deliberately disregards critical environmental news and information.
link_name: Marty Kaplan on Why the Media Ignores Climate Change

status_message: The Republican willingness — indeed, eagerness — to abandon traditional norms of governing has crippled our political system, writes Paul Waldman at The Week.
link_name: How the Merrick Garland nomination explains the rise of Donald Trump

status_message:
An analysis by ProPublica has found that there is a relationship between what drugs doctors prescribe and payments they get from pharmaceutical companies.  

"Doctors who got money from drug and device makers—even just a meal– prescribed a higher percentage of brand-name drugs overall than doctors who didn't, our analysis showed. Indeed, doctors who received industry payments were two to three times as likely to prescribe brand-name drugs at exceptionally high rates as others in their specialty."
link_name: Now There's Proof: Docs Who Take Company Cash Tend to Prescribe More Brand-Name Drugs

status_message: In their new book, Nation on the Take, Wendell Potter and Nick Penniman portray a government and politics polluted by big corporate dollars. But the authors also offer solutions.
link_name: Potter and Penniman: "The System Is Rigged Against Regular People" - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
President Obama has shown little interest in gambling his environmental legacy in his final year of office, writes Grist.org. 

"Rather than slow down after the Paris climate change conference in December, he has pushed forward on policies climate activists say are necessary to keep fossil fuels in the ground — first, his administration announced a moratorium on new coal leases, and now, it has taken the Atlantic Coast off the table for drillers.

The administration released a new version of its five-year plan for offshore drilling on Tuesday, and the most significant change is its reversal on its plan from a year ago to open the mid-Atlantic to offshore development. The Arctic, meanwhile, is still open for business."
link_name: Obama's offshore drilling plan, mostly a win for environmentalists with a caveat

status_message: Why isn't Congress serving the American people? Dysfunction, partisan ravings and obstruction, political scholars Norman Ornstein and Thomas Mann tell Bill.
link_name: Norman Ornstein and Thomas Mann Explain Why Congress is Failing Us

status_message: Here's how the pharmaceutical industry keeps America's drug prices among the highest in the world.
link_name: The Lobbyist Who Made You Pay More at the Drugstore - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
An analysis of US Environmental Protection Agency data by USA TODAY "showed about 350 schools and day-care centers failed lead tests a total of about 470 times from 2012 through 2015.
That represents nearly 20% of the water systems nationally testing above the agency's 'action level' of 15 parts per billion."
link_name: Lead taints drinking water in hundreds of schools, day cares across USA

status_message:
"Plastic bag companies and their allies have pitched in more than $5 million to qualify two November ballot measures they hope will kill a statewide ban on their product and prevent grocery stores from benefiting from the sale of bags," according to the The Sacramento Bee. 

"In 2014, lawmakers banned single-use bags at grocery stores, pharmacies, smaller markets and convenience stores in the state. The law was slated to take full effect on July 1, 2016."
link_name: Plastic bag referendum tallies $5 million in contributions

status_message:
We haven't heard much about the nuances of foreign policy in the ongoing presidential campaign, writes Truthout. 

"Every candidate intends to "destroy" the Islamic State; each has concerns about Russian President Vladimir Putin, North Korea, and China; every one of them will defend Israel; and no one wants to talk much about anything else -- except, in the case of the Republicans, who rattle their sabers against Iran." 

Number one -- Is There an Endgame for the Global War on Terror?
link_name: Five Unanswered Foreign Policy Questions in the 2016 Presidential Race

status_message:
Obama weighs in for Hillary –> Maggie Haberman and Michael D. Shear for The New York Times: "In unusually candid remarks, President Obama privately told a group of Democratic donors last Friday that Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont was nearing the point at which his campaign against Hillary Clinton would end, and that the party must soon come together to back her. 

"Mr. Obama acknowledged that Mrs. Clinton was perceived to have weaknesses as a candidate, and that some Democrats did not view her as authentic. But he played down the importance of authenticity, noting that President George W. Bush — whose record he ran aggressively against in 2008 — was once praised for his authenticity."
link_name: Morning Reads: Obama Tells Donors to Get Behind Clinton; Michigan Governor, EPA Get Slammed For...

status_message:
The FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler is likely to circulate soon a proposal to approve Charter's bid to buy Time Warner Cable, according to The Wall Street Journal. 

"The FCC's proposed order will likely come with a number of conditions and could be modified later after the other commissioners review it. But approval of the $55 billion deal would be a victory for Charter after Comcast ended its acquisition bid last year because of regulatory concerns over harm to the online video market," writes The Hill.
link_name: Report: FCC nears approval of Charter-Time Warner Cable deal

status_message:
The brilliant reporter and editor who sounded the alarm against media monopoly called on us all to be stewards of democracy. 

"No American citizen can vote intelligently without knowledge of the ideas, political background, and commitments of each individual candidate," Bagdikian wrote in 1997. "No national paper or broadcast station can report adequately the issues and candidates in every one of the 65,000 local voting districts. Only locally based journalism can do it, and if it does not, voters become captives of the only alternative information, paid political propaganda, or no information at all."
link_name: Ben Bagdikian Knew That Journalism Must Serve the People—Not the Powerful

status_message: A Trump presidency ranks among the Economist Intelligence Unit's top 10 global risks this month, in part because his "militaristic tendencies towards the Middle East (and ban on all Muslim travel to the US) would be a potent recruitment tool for jihadi groups, increasing their threat both within the region and beyond."
link_name: Global Forecasting Service - Donald Trump wins the US presidential election

status_message: A successful energy transition to renewables could not only rescue the planet but create a more just economy. It would lead to an estimated 2.7 million new jobs, according to economists at the University of Massachusetts Amherst's Political Economy Research Institute - PERI.
link_name: What Keeping Oil in the Ground Can Do for Economic Inequality

status_message:
"A court in Washington has ruled that the Grocery Manufacturers Association violated the state's finance disclosure law when it funneled millions of dollars in dark money from its major corporate members to the campaign that defeated a 2013 ballot initiative to label food containing genetically modified organisms, or GMOs. 

The GMA could face up to a $33 million fine if a trial court determines that members of its staff knew they were breaking the law when they attempted to hide the identities of processed food companies opposed to the ballot initiative, which would have required special labels for grocery items containing GMO ingredients," reports Truthout.
link_name: Opponents of GMO Labeling Broke Washington's Campaign Finance Law

status_message: Linda Greenhouse, a longtime Court watcher, writes at The New York Times that, in memory of Robert Bork, the conservative Reagan appointee Democrats refused to confirm in 1987, the GOP is sending a message to Democrats: "You did it to one of ours, so now we'll do it to one of yours. Really? To Merrick B. Garland, the chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, who after two decades on the bench is one of the country's most respected and experienced federal judges?"
link_name: Morning Reads: Will the GOP Hold Its Ground on Obama's SCOTUS Pick? - BillMoyers.com

status_message: "In the Democratic race, Hillary Clinton won Florida, Illinois, North Carolina and Ohio, and leads Senator Bernie Sanders by only about 1,500 votes in Missouri. As Sanders began his address on Tuesday night, Fox News, CNN and MSNBC all declined to cut away, instead offering pundits' commentary and graphics promising they would soon go to Donald Trump's address," writes Truthout.
link_name: Hillary Clinton Has Big Night; Media Move to Silence Bernie Sanders' Campaign

status_message: Former GOP presidential candidate Ben Carson said while he wished there was a "path" for him to endorse another Republican candidate, Trump seemed like the only realistic option. He also implied that in exchange for his endorsement, Trump offered the neurosurgeon a role in his administration.
link_name: Carson: I Didn't Really Want To Endorse Trump, But He Offered Me A Position (VIDEO)

status_message: "Despite his vote with the majority in a key case that opened the door for super PACs, the 63-year-old federal judge whom President Barack Obama nominated to the Supreme Court today has a record that suggests he'd favor more regulation of money in politics, some campaign finance reformers say," writes John Light.
link_name: Merrick Garland Could Mean a New Chapter in the Fight to Reverse Citizens United

status_message:
Robert Reich used to support trade agreements but does not support the "new-style" agreements like the TPP. 

"The Trans Pacific Trade Partnership's investor protections will make it safer for firms to relocate abroad – the Cato Institute describes such protections as "lowering the risk premium" on offshoring – thereby further reducing corporate incentives to make and do things in the United States, using and upgrading the skills of Americans.

Almost all the growth goes to the richest 1 percent. The rest of us can buy some products cheaper than before, but most of those gains would are offset by wage losses."
link_name: The New Truth About Free Trade

status_message: Our Trump files are expanding! This week, as new investigations are unfolding, we pull back the curtains a bit further, revealing more of Trump's history of public and private prejudice, of outsourcing to low-wage countries and of profiting from business ventures while leaving partners, shareholders and customers devastated.  Thank you to our readers who have contributed.
link_name: billmoyers.com

status_message: Olivia Nuzzi writes for The Daily Beast that a contested convention looms: "While Trump winnowed the field and grew his delegate lead closer to the 1,237 threshold needed to secure the Republican nomination, he didn't do well enough to put an end to the race altogether. John Kasich, the governor of Ohio, won his home state by a decisive 10-point margin. To win now, Trump will need to claim 57 percent of the remaining delegates, and the odds of a contested convention, once considered highly improbable, are greater than ever."
link_name: Morning Reads: Republicans Barrel Toward the Political Nerd's Dream, a Contested Convention -...

status_message: A mini-history of our last century of turmoil through a kaleidoscope of characters, courtesy of Award-winning Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano.
link_name: billmoyers.com

status_message: Happy Birthday to Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who turns 83 today. Her blistering dissent in the 2012 ruling that gutted the Voting Rights Act of 1965 helped earn her the AKA of  Notorious R.B.G. It's also one of seven top dissents that we highlighted by the Roberts Court. (#1 and #5 are courtesy of Ginsburg)
link_name: Great Moments From Roberts Court Dissents

status_message: Trump's the symptom, not the disease. The Republican establishment has been infecting the body politic for years, write Bill Moyers and Michael Winship.
link_name: The GOP Elites Have Themselves to Blame

status_message:
North Carolina's controversial new voter ID law goes into effect for the first time today in the state's election primary, and 218,000 registered voters do not have an acceptable form of government-issued ID now required to vote. 

Here, journalist Ari Berman chronicles the struggles both young and old voters to obtain the necessary ID, including a 94-year-old woman who had to make 11 trips to different state agencies in 2015 to comply with the new law.
link_name: North Carolina's Voter ID Law Could Block 218,000 Registered Voters From the Polls

status_message:
The Justice Department has called on state judges to end unconstitutional policies targeting the poor-- and warned against operating courthouses as "for-profit ventures." 

The Justice Department, "chastised judges and court staff members for using arrest warrants as a way to collect fees. Such policies... made it more likely that poor people would be arrested, jailed and fined anew — all for being unable to pay in the first place."

Following an investigation of the Police Department and court in Ferguson, Missouri last year, the Justice Department concluded that the court was a moneymaking venture, not an independent branch of government.
link_name: Justice Dept. Condemns Profit-Minded Court Policies Targeting the Poor

status_message: Record-breaking February –> "Last month was far and away the hottest February on record for the planet, by a margin that has surprised even the climate scientists who closely monitor global temperature data. It was also the most anomalously warm month Earth has seen in 135 years of… record keeping, continuing an astonishing recent streak that could see 2016 set a new record for hottest year," Andrea Thompson reports for Climate Central.
link_name: Morning Reads: Yet Another Month Blows Away Heat Records - BillMoyers.com

status_message: In this video, Demos President Heather McGhee and Ian Haney Lopez, author of Dog Whistle Politics, talk about how racism fuels economic inequality -- using clips from Ronald Reagan and his former advisor, Lee Atwater, to help prove their point.
link_name: Demos

status_message:
In the world's oceans, birds, whales, sea turtles and other animals often mistake plastic for food. Scientists are currently researching the long-term impacts of this, including potential impacts on human health, writes Truthout. 

Billions of pounds of plastic have bounded together to form gyres --  swirling masses across the surface and into the depths of water --  which currently cover almost 40 percent of the world's ocean surfaces.
link_name: More Plastic Than Fish in Oceans by 2050 Helps Drive Calls for Reduced Plastic Use

status_message:
How transparent are lawmakers in your state? The Associated Press writes that they sent open-records requests to the top lawmakers in all 50 states and most governors, seeking copies of their daily schedules and emails from the government accounts for the week of Feb. 1-7. 

The AP received more denials than approvals from lawmakers. You can see how your state responded to these requests here. #SunshineWeek
link_name: SUNSHINE WEEK: How open record laws are applied in state legislatures

status_message: On this day in 1879, Albert Einstein was born in Ulm, Germany. Albert Einstein's quip that "God does not play dice with the universe," was about quantum physics, not a statement of faith. But he did ponder the relationship between science and religion and his sense of "the order deeply hidden behind everything." Two theoretical physicists join Krista Tippett to explore Einstein's wisdom on mystery, eternity and the mind of God.
link_name: Conversations on the Intersection Between Faith and Science | BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Devolution –> The campaign trail this weekend was chaotic. On Friday, at a Trump rally in St. Louis, protesters kept the candidate from speaking several times; later that day, in Chicago, the campaign announced that the candidate would not show up at a rally after protesters turned out by the thousands. On Saturday, police attacked protesters outside a Trump rally in Kansas City with pepper spray.

On Sunday morning, Trump threatened Bernie Sanders supporters in a tweet: "Bernie Sanders is lying when he says his disruptors aren't told to go to my events. Be careful Bernie, or my supporters will go to yours!" And on Meet the Press, he said he was considering paying the legal fees of the 78-year-old man who sucker punched a black protester at a rally last week. Sanders denied Trump's allegations and called Trump "a pathological liar."
link_name: Morning Reads: As Rallies Grow More Violent, Trump Threatens Sanders - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
There's been plenty of presidential debates and town halls, but many "critical foreign policy questions" are barely getting coverage, says writer and activist Trevor Timm.

"These topics that will be crucial for the next president, yet are rarely if ever brought up. Why aren't they being raised at every opportunity?"
link_name: The Five Foreign Policy Questions Every Candidate Should Be Asked

status_message:
The kind of violence that we're seeing on the campaign trail -- and not just inside the Trump campaign -- is the result of dog-whistle politics that keep Americans divided, says Robert Reich. 

Demos fellow Ian Haney-López, an expert on the topic, talks here about how politicians have mastered the use of dog whistles, which he calls "the dark magic" by which middle-class voters have been seduced to vote against their own economic interests.
link_name: Ian Haney López on the Dog Whistle Politics of Race

status_message: How did we get here? Have a look at the down and dirty history of secret spending, PACs, and dark money.
link_name: 250 Years of Campaigns, Cash and Corruption | BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Eight in 10 of working-class Americans feel like the country is still in a recession, says Robert P. Jones, co-author of the American Values Survey. "They have been hit pretty hard by jobs that pay by the hour, [that] have been pretty stagnant or even losing value over time. So I think it's a volatile cocktail of economics, cultural changes and demographic changes all moving in the same direction, fueling these anxieties."

According to the survey, about three-quarters of Trump supporters agree that, today, discrimination against whites has become as big a problem as discrimination against blacks and other minorities.
link_name: So, Who Are Donald Trump's Voters?

status_message:
New research shows how 401(k)'s are completely failing the poor and middle class. 

Barely over half of families have any sort of account at all, and the median balance among all families is $5,000, according to an article in THE WEEK.
link_name: Why the 401(k) system is a blight on the face of the American republic

status_message: Fossil fuel interests have contributed $3.25 million into the largest super PAC supporting Hillary Clinton's presidential run. "Approximately one in every 15 dollars given to Priorities USA Action, which took in $50.5 million in contributions last year, came from donors linked to oil and natural gas interests, according to data compiled by Greenpeace.
link_name: Fossil Fuel Investors Are Pumping Millions of Dollars Into Hillary Clinton's Campaign | VICE News

status_message: Robert Reich has been reluctant to use the "f" word to describe Donald Trump, he writes, but "Trump has finally reached a point where parallels between his presidential campaign and the fascists of the first half of the 20th century – lurid figures such as Benito Mussolini, Joseph Stalin, Adolf Hitler, Oswald Mosley, and Francisco Franco – are too evident to overlook."
link_name: Trump: The American Fascist - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Many Republicans, especially Christian fundamentalists, have decoupled from the real world — and are proud of it. The more that GOP candidates embrace "anti-knowledge" the more popular they become, as Mike Lofgren explains.
link_name: The GOP and the Rise of Anti-Knowledge

status_message: Bernie Sanders criticized the North American Free Trade Agreement, as well as the TPP, on the campaign trail this week saying that such trade policies "are resulting in the disappearance of the American middle class," Twenty years after NAFTA, Public Citizen compared the promises with which NAFTA was sold and what end up happening to jobs, trade balances and immigration as a result.
link_name: Report: NAFTA Turns 20

status_message:
"Where am I controversial? When it comes to the use of military power," Obama said. "That is the source of the controversy. There's a playbook in Washington that presidents are supposed to follow. It's a playbook that comes out of the foreign-policy establishment." 

"And the playbook prescribes responses to different events, and these responses tend to be militarized responses. Where America is directly threatened, the playbook works. But the playbook can also be a trap that can lead to bad decisions. In the midst of an international challenge like Syria, you get judged harshly if you don't follow the playbook, even if there are good reasons why it does not apply." -- From The Atlantic's cover story on President Barack Obama's foreign policy strategies.
link_name: The Obama Doctrine

status_message:
On Wednesday, 21 youth plaintiffs -- including environmental activist Kelsey Juliana -- appeared in a federal court for a hearing on a complaint filed on their behalf by the nonprofit Our Children's Trust. 

They're suing the US government and President Barak Obama for failing to act quickly enough to stop climate change. Kelsey walked 1,600 miles from Nebraska to Washington, DC in 2014 to raise awareness about the climate crisis. "I have everything to gain from taking action and everything to lose from not," Juliana told Bill in an interview.
link_name: Kelsey Juliana on Climate Change: The Next Generation

status_message: New research finds than six in ten Americans are represented by someone in Congress who denies the reality of climate change. And climate deniers have received over $73 million from dirty energy companies in the coal, oil and gas industries,
link_name: Most Americans Disagree With Their Congressional Representative On Climate Change

status_message:
NPR writes that voters in North Carolina are likely to be confused when they arrive at their polling places on March 15. 

"In addition to presidential candidates, voters will see congressional primary candidates on the ballot. But thanks to a federal court decision [and one hastily redrawn Congressional map] the districts those candidates represent no longer exist and any votes in those races won't count."

Said one observer, "Some sitting members of Congress woke up the next morning after these maps had been released and went, 'Oh, boy, I don't even live in the district now.'"
link_name: North Carolina's Congressional Primaries Are A Mess Because Of These Maps

status_message:
"The media have been acting as if the Trump debacle were the biggest political story to come down the pike in some time. 

But the real story – one the popularity of Trump's candidacy has revealed and inarguably the biggest political story of the last 50 years — is the decades-long transformation of Republicanism from a business-centered, small town, white Protestant set of beliefs into quite possibly America's primary institutional force of bigotry, intellectual dishonesty, ignorance, warmongering, intractability and cruelty against the vulnerable and powerless."
link_name: Blowing the Biggest Political Story of the Last Fifty Years - By Neal Gabler

status_message:
Republican debate –> No anatomy jokes here. The candidates focused on "issues" instead of personal attacks at last night's debate in Miami. But, Jeb Lund at The Guardian quipped, "Just because it's quieter doesn't make it any smarter." 

Ezra Klein at Vox: "Was this debate substantive? Sure, in the sense that it focused on weighty policy topics like Social Security and trade and the assembled candidates mostly used their inside voices. But the things the candidates actually said were, by turns, wrong, misleading, misinformed, confused, or ridiculous. This substantive debate mostly showed how weak a grasp on the issues the candidates actually have."
link_name: Morning Reads: GOP Candidates Dive Into the Issues, Come Up Empty-Handed - BillMoyers.com

status_message: "We have a lot of divides that are artificial or not carefully examined. People on both the Right and Left are operating with a lot of stereotypes about each other." -- Writer and activist Rebecca Solnit discusses the presidential elections, social change and her love of walking.
link_name: Rebecca Solnit Explains Things to Us

status_message: Two political scientists debunk five persistent myths about the Koch brothers and their political operation. Myth # 1: The Koch network is a recent reaction to the Obama presidency.
link_name: Five Myths About The Koch Network — And Why It Matters To Set Them Straight

status_message:
While President Obama and Congress are pushing for more military spending next year, voters see things very differently.  

"The nonpartisan organization The Voice Of People recently gave registered voters around the country the task of forming their own defense budgets, after hearing vetted pro and con arguments, and it found that 61 percent favored cutting defense spending an average of $12 billion," writes Lauren Chadwick at The Center for Public Integrity.
link_name: Most voters favor cutting defense spending. Politicians say otherwise

status_message: There's one newspaper left in the area, a weekly with only two reporters covering a community of 125,000 near Seattle, Washington. "With no public discussion and nobody looking on, [the Kent City Council] agreed to sell a 10-acre public park to a developer to be turned into a housing subdivision," writes Danny Westneat in The Seattle Times.
link_name: With no watchdog media, Kent made hush-hush sale of public park

status_message:
Twenty-one kids were in court yesterday demanding that the federal government take action to address climate change. A federal judge in Oregon will determine whether their case can move forward. 

From our report, co-published with Grist.org:

"The complaint alleges violation of the kids' Fifth Amendment rights to due process and equal protection. By failing to act on climate change, it argues, the government discriminates against youth as a class. Without access to a healthy climate, they're deprived of their fundamental rights to life, liberty and property."
link_name: Should Kids Be Able to Sue For a Safe Climate? This Federal Court is About to Decide

status_message: Student debt held by people between 50 and 80 years old has more than doubled since 2003, writes Sarah Jaffe. Older people actually hold a significant portion of the $1.3 trillion student debt bubble and Social Security can be garnished to pay down student debt.
link_name: The For-Profit College Scam That These Students Are Still Paying For - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
Debate –> The Democratic campaign shifted yet again following Bernie Sanders' surprise Tuesday night victory in Michigan, reminding commentators once more that conventional knowledge (and polls) no longer count for much. In a Univision/Washington Post-hosted debate last night, Sanders and Hillary Clinton traded attacks on immigration. 

Alex Seitz-Wald and Amanda Sakuma at MSNBC: "Both pledged they would not deport children nor undocumented adults without criminal records… The debate went into the weeds on Senate procedure and while campaign staff flooded reporters' inboxes with fact checks and research, both candidates — who have spent decades in public life as feelings on immigration have evolved — emerged with muddied and imperfect records on the issue."
link_name: Morning Reads: Dems Spar on Immigration; What to Make of Tuesday's Sanders Victory? - BillMoyers.com

status_message: The vast majority of guns used in 15 recent mass shootings, including at least two of the guns used in the San Bernardino attack, were bought legally and with a federal background check. At least 8 gunmen had criminal histories or documented mental health problems that did not prevent them from obtaining their weapons.
link_name: How They Got Their Guns

status_message: Alexander Hamilton, that visionary Founding Father and hip-hop phenomenon, thanks to Hamilton, the musical, has been celebrated of late on Broadway and at the Grammys. His face adorns the $10 bill. If only his thoughts about choosing Supreme Court justices were getting remotely as much respect from Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, Judiciary Committee Chairman Charles Grassley and most other GOP senators.
link_name: Shun a President's Supreme Court Nominee? Alexander Hamilton Would Not Be Pleased

status_message: Readers express concern that the Fourth Estate is in serious trouble in reaction to The Nation's cover story about major newsroom layoffs at papers across the country. Here's one: "I came up during Watergate when Woodward and Bernstein and other investigative journalists were our heroes and journalism schools enrollments exploded. Oh my god, how far we have fallen." -- Dawn Singh on Facebook.
link_name: Your Turn: America's Increasingly Vacant Newsrooms

status_message: More than two-thirds of the income of the top 400 taxpayers comes from investment income taxed at about half the rate as income earned from work: capital gains accounted for 51.7 percent of top 400 taxpayers' income; dividends 10.8 percent and interest, 5.8 percent.
link_name: 7 Things You Didn't Know About The Ultra Rich | Inequality.org

status_message:
Tuesday –> Donald Trump's campaign remains strong; last night he won nomination contests in Michigan, Mississippi and Hawaii, despite a wave of attack ads and backlash in the wake of last week's solid Super Tuesday showing. 

But the big surprise of the evening was a Michigan win for Bernie Sanders, who was predicted to lose the state, in some cases by double digits. Instead, he won, with 49.9 percent of the vote. Hillary Clinton won Mississippi, and Ted Cruz won Idaho; the overall delegate math remains mostly unchanged.
link_name: Morning Reads: A Surprise Win for Sanders, No Surprises for Trump - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Interactive election maps by Mother Jones show who won the Republican and Democratic races and how many delegates each candidate took.
link_name: The 2016 presidential primary delegate tracker

status_message:
ABC, CBS, NBC, and Fox spent less time covering climate change in 2015, even though there were more newsworthy climate-related events -- such as 195 countries around the world reaching a historic climate agreement in Paris. 

ABC spent only 13 minutes of its total news coverage to the issue of climate change in 2015.
link_name: STUDY: How Broadcast Networks Covered Climate Change In 2015

status_message:
Trump echoed Mitt Romney's 47 percent comment last June on Fox when he depicted 50 percent of Americans as people seeking a free ride. Trump said: "[O]ne half of the nation is carrying the other half, and the attitude of those in the latter half is, 'we don't have to do anything.'"

But here's what the numbers say, as described by David Corn in Mother Jones: "In 2011, 60 percent of those who didn't pay income taxes did pay taxes for Social Security and Medicare. These people essentially did not make enough money to qualify for the income tax. Another 22 percent of the people who didn't pay income taxes were retirees. Only 8 percent of US households paid no federal taxes at all. According to Washington Post analysis, that was 'usually because they're either unemployed or on disability or students or are very poor.'"
link_name: Donald Trump's 47 percent moment.

status_message: "First Nations and environmental activists in the Pacific Northwest have spun a web of resistance by delaying oil refining equipment headed to Alberta tar sands, occupying lands slated for pipelines, locking down rail lines carrying coal trains and skirmishing on the water with drill rigs headed for the Arctic," Arun Gupta writes for YES! Magazine.
link_name: The West Coast Is the World's 5th Largest Economy. Can It Unite to Stop Big Oil?

status_message: On TalkPoverty.org, Stephanie Land writes about the comments and criticism she receives when talking about the challenges of raising her daughters on a very low income.
link_name: Who Are the 'Legitimate' Poor?

status_message:
Bloomberg says no –> The media mogul and former New York City mayor announced in a column for his company's Bloomberg View that he will not run for president. 

At The New York Times, Maggie Haberman and Alexander Burns report that Bloomberg had put together a robust campaign infrastructure — but polling showed that he could not win enough states to reach the 270 votes required in the Electoral College. With a three-way split among candidates, a Republican Congress would decide the outcome of the election, and Bloomberg didn't want to risk the possibility of a President Cruz or Trump.
link_name: Morning Reads: Bloomberg Won't Run, Fearing a President Trump or Cruz - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Ahead of International Women's Day, here's a look at The Economist's glass-ceiling index, which aims to reveal where women have the best chances of equal treatment at work.  The US scored 56 out of 100 possible points.
link_name: The best—and worst—places to be a working woman

status_message: "A divided Federal Election Commission cannot agree to investigate whether super PAC donors used corporations to mask their identities in the 2012 campaign, effectively giving a green light to contributors writing checks through limited-liability companies in this year's elections," writes Matea Gold of Washington Post.
link_name: The FEC just made it easier for super PAC donors to hide their identities

status_message:
U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren writes about Washington's "assault" on Social Security for TalkPoverty.org. 

"We've heard over and over that we supposedly need to gut the program in order to "save" it. But for the 21 million Americans whose Social Security benefits are the only thing keeping them out of poverty, Social Security isn't a luxury—it's a lifeline. 

The absolute last thing we should do—at the very moment that Social Security has become so essential to millions of our seniors—is to allow the program to be dismantled inch by inch."
link_name: Why Seniors—Not CEOs—Deserve a Raise

status_message:
William Greider writes about an "ugly surprise" in store for the American people -- a $400 billion tax break for US multinational corporations that politicians in Washington are currently working on. 

"[T]he threat of corporate flight is now made explicit by the lobbyists and cheerleaders: If Congress doesn't give them a sufficiently generous tax break, some of the biggest corporate names may decide to leave. Instead of repealing the outrageous loopholes, gullible members of Congress now claim they have no choice but to appease the bankers, the techies and the drugmakers." -- Greider in The Nation.
link_name: Democrats and Republicans Are Quietly Planning a $400 Billion Corporate Giveaway

status_message: The Washington Spectator's Rick Perlstein writes: "My fear is the fact that, on January 20, 2017, a President Sanders would be inaugurated politically naked and alone — commanding a party apparatus less prepared ideologically, institutionally and legislatively to do great things than at any time in its history."
link_name: Sanders, Clinton and the Democrats' Dilemma

status_message:
The brutal death of 26-year-old Jimmie Lee Jackson --  a deacon and woodcutter who simply wanted to exercise his right to vote -- led Martin Luther King, Jr. aide James Bevel to introduce the idea of marching from Selma to Montgomery on March 7, 1965 to protest his death.

Jackson had tried to register to vote five times in Perry County, where only 265 of 5,202 eligible black voters were on the voting rolls. On February 18, 1965 at a gathering of 200 protesters, an Alabama state trooper shot him point-blank in the stomach as he tried to protect his mother. #Selma
link_name: Remembering Jimmie Lee Jackson, the First Martyr of the Selma Struggle

status_message: Debate in Flint –> At Vox, Libby Nelson and Dara Lind declare three winners of Sunday's Democratic debate in Flint, Michigan, much of which focused on the city's water crisis and the region's economic problems: the two candidates, and the city of Flint itself.
link_name: Morning Reads: Democrats Zero In on the Flint Disaster and the Plight of Rust Belt Cities

status_message: Where do the Republican candidates stand on the issues - and how do they fit on an ideological spectrum alongside past American presidents? BBC News charts the candidates on national security, immigration, abortion, foreign policy.
link_name: US election 2016: How Donald Trump compares to Ronald Reagan - BBC News

status_message: Approximately one third of the world's food supply—or about 1.3 billion tons of food—is wasted each year, according to the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP)... The U.S. is the world's greatest food waster while South Korea is the world's largest food recycler. In Copenhagen, a new supermarket, WeFood, can help Danish residents cut down on food waste and their grocery bills, TakePart reported. How? By selling "rescued food" to customers at a more cost efficient price than other neighborhood grocery stores.
link_name: Initiatives to Curb Food Waste Go Into Effect in Denmark, South Korea

status_message: "[Trump] is saying the things that a lot of people already believed but were too polite or afraid to say in public," writes Saqib Bhatt, a fellow at the Roosevelt Institute who is an American-born son of Pakistani Muslim immigrants. "He is also telling Muslims something that deep down many of us have long feared but were afraid to say out loud: We don't belong here. There is something very unsettling about it, like someone peeking into your deepest, most personal insecurity, and shining a bright light on it."
link_name: Why Donald Trump Sends a Chill Through My Muslim-American Body

status_message: In this documentary, originally aired in 2007, Bill and his team investigate big media's role as cheerleader in the months preceding the 2003 invasion of Iraq. How did the mainstream press get it so wrong in the run-up to the war? "Buying the War" includes interviews with Dan Rather, Tim Russet, Bob Simon and the Knight Ridder team that investigated the intelligence agencies to try and determine if there was any evidence for the Bush Administration's case for war.
link_name: Buying the War: How Big Media Failed Us

status_message: We're checking the accuracy of what the presidential candidates are saying this week, via PolitiFact.
link_name: Statements from National: 2016 U.S. President | PolitiFact

status_message: Donald Trump is likely to go down as "the most consequential presidential candidate" in at least the last 50 years, writes historian Andrew Bacevich. "He has already transformed the tone and temper of American political life. If he becomes the Republican nominee, he will demolish its structural underpinnings as well. Should he prevail in November, his election will alter its very fabric in ways likely to prove irreversible. Whether Trump ever delivers on his promise to 'Make America Great Again,' he is already transforming American democratic practice.
link_name: Don't Cry for Me, America: What Trumpism Means for Democracy

status_message: When discussing a groundbreaking book on inequality, economist Paul Krugman tells Bill that America is on the road to becoming a society controlled by those with inherited wealth, like "Gordon Gekko's son or daughter."
link_name: Paul Krugman on Gordon Gekko's Daughter and America's Inherited Wealth Problem

status_message:
"Since the Citizens United decision came down, nonprofit groups have formed to back candidates. And unlike the super PACs, the nonprofits are not required to report who their donors are. That's because these groups are theoretically focused on 'social welfare,' not politics. 

It's a highly cynical and dubious claim in many cases, but it's working... This election, secrecy has been pushed to another level."
link_name: Commentary: The consequences of our secret elections

status_message: "The tragic lead poisoning of the Flint water supply in Michigan is a study in bureaucratic bungling, racial inequity, and national media inattention. But the fallout from the crisis has obscured another lesson: There are consequences when those in power are able to simply circumvent the public will," writes ProPublica.
link_name: The Referendum That Might Have Headed Off Flint's Water Crisis

status_message: This week, the Supreme Court began hearing arguments in the first significant test of abortion rights in a decade. The Nation Magazine's Zoë Carpenter writes: "In the summer of 2013, Texas enacted a law (HB2) 'to improve the standard of care for abortion patients... Defenders of HB2 say their intent is not to make abortions harder to get, but to make them safer. Never mind that the medical community says there is 'no medical basis' for the regulations, or that other procedures with similar or greater risks aren't subject to the same rules...Unless you think the American Medical Association, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and the American Academy of Family Physicians are a bunch of know-nothings, it's hard to see Texas' health-based argument for HB2 as anything but what it is: total baloney."
link_name: ﻿The Big Lie at the Heart of the Texas Abortion Clinic Case

status_message: Juan Cole's post on the media's role in Donald Trump's ascendency led to thousands of comments on BillMoyers.com and Facebook – with over 17,000 people sharing it there. Here are some highlights.
link_name: Your Turn: Pumping Up Trump - BillMoyers.com

status_message: In 1989, Bill investigated how news organizations increasingly served the interests of politicians, rather than the general public. The short clip in this post explores how video images had become "the new language of politics." How things have stayed the same -- and changed.  #flashbackfriday
link_name: Illusions of News

status_message: The mainstream media is to blame for Donald Trump's rise, but not for the reasons most people think, writes author and journalist Neal Gabler.
link_name: How the Media Enabled Donald Trump by Destroying Politics First

status_message: "The ground is shifting beneath the financial sector, and big banks could soon become a thing of the past," writes Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s Simon Johnson.
link_name: The End of Big Banks

status_message: In 2007, there were 55,000 full-time journalists at nearly 1,400 daily papers. By 2015, that number had dropped to 32,900. As newsrooms disappear, veteran older reporters are being forced from the profession. That's bad for journalism — and democracy.
link_name: What Happens to Journalists When No One Wants to Print Their Words Anymore?

status_message: A new scientific study released yesterday delivered more bad news about Greenland. "The ice sheet is 'darkening,' or losing its ability to reflect both visible and invisible radiation, as it melts more and more, the research finds. That means it's absorbing more of the sun's energy — which then drives further melting," writes the Washington Post's Chris Mooney.
link_name: Greenland's melting is 'feeding on itself,' scientists say

status_message:
GOP debate –> At yet another debate last night, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio took a spaghetti-at-the-wall approach in their attempts to bring down Donald Trump. The New York Times offers some fact checks, Mother Jones highlights some key moments, and some ridiculous ones. John Nichols writes at The Nation Magazine: "The 11th Republican presidential 'debate' was not a debate. It was 'The Donald Trump Show,' with also-ran candidates and Fox News personalities playing bit parts. It was a long, drab waste of time that did nothing to weaken Trump."

He's back –> Yesterday morning, Mitt Romney took center stage to denounce Donald Trump. But commentators were quick to note that Romney once sought the same voters whose anger, resentment and feelings of marginalization Trump now harnesses. The New York Times editorial board wrote that Trump's "forced a Republican Party reckoning overdue for years, all in a few days. It took the Trump-dominated Super Tuesday contests to awaken Republican leaders to the fact that the darkest elements of the party's base, which many of them have embraced or exploited, are now threatening their party."
link_name: Morning Reads: Trump Fiddles as GOP Melts Down - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Most Americans want President Obama to nominate someone to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court. Overall, 58% say they'd like to see the President nominate someone to the Court rather than leave the seat vacant until a new president takes office next year, while 41% would prefer a vacancy, according to a CNN poll (sampling error of +/- plus of 3%).
link_name: For the next Justice, Americans want a nominee and a hearing

status_message: The Economic Policy Institute today delivered some hard evidence on the problems facing the average American retiree. "The shift from defined benefit pensions to 401(k)'s 'has failed the majority of workers.'" It's increased wealth inequality for older workers and left them on average with meager resources.
link_name: How severe is the retirement crisis? These six charts spell it out.

status_message: Michael Winship compares the nasty rhetoric of politics today to the language of earlier times, when citing the classics was considered a sign of intelligence. On April 4 1968, while out campaigning, presidential candidate Bobby Kennedy revealed the shocking news that Martin Luther King, Jr. had been assassinated. Kennedy calmed the spectators, speaking about the need for "love, and wisdom, and compassion toward one another," before quoting Aeschylus, the poet and dramatist of ancient Greece. (We found video of Kennedy's impromptu speech, which you can watch here.)
link_name: When the Poetry of Campaigning Becomes a Cheesy, Dirty Limerick

status_message: Bernie Sanders's aggressive agenda on environmental issues has given climate activists a goalpost to steer Hillary Clinton toward. And it's been working, writes John Light.
link_name: Hillary Clinton's Green Evolution

status_message: January and February of 2016 set record lows for Arctic sea ice writes Chris Mooney at the Washington Post.
link_name: The 'ridiculously' warm Arctic just set an ominous new record

status_message: The women take over –> Slate.com's Dahlia Lithwick reports that in the opening day of arguments in this year's landmark abortion case, Whole Woman's Health v Hellerstedt, "it felt as if, for the first time in history, the gender playing field at the high court was finally leveled" and the women justices "were emboldened to just ignore the rules. …There was something wonderful and symbolic about Roberts losing almost complete control over the court's indignant women, who are just not inclined to play nice anymore."
link_name: Morning Reads: The Women on the Bench Take Over - BillMoyers.com

status_message:
"Mr. Trump is the perfect 'shock jock' candidate; he and big media are strange bedfellows – each feeds off the other." - commenter on BillMoyers.com  

See highlights from the thousands of comments we received in response to Juan Cole's article: "Media Make Excuses for Trump Voters."
link_name: Your Turn: Pumping Up Trump

status_message: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, set up by Elizabeth Warren in 2008, has created pending new regulations to protect Americans from payday loan sharks, companies that make enormous profits off of predatory lending - and the poor. Now, the DNC has joined the GOP in attacking their effort. The chair of the DNC is co-sponsoring a new bill that would effectively "gut the CFPB's forthcoming payday loan regulations, The Huffington Post reports.
link_name: DNC Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz joins hands with GOP in assault on Elizabeth Warren's ...

status_message:
"Trump has said many offensive things about Latinos, African Americans, Jews, Asian Americans, women and the LGBTQ community, to name a few. 

But of all the bigoted statements he has made, the one that hits me the hardest — perhaps the only one that hits me at all any more — is his call for a Muslim ban," writes Saqib Bhatti.  

"I don't think Trump is spreading bigotry and racism in this country — I think he is unleashing it. He is saying the things that a lot of people already believed but were too polite or afraid to say in public."
link_name: Why Donald Trump Sends a Chill Through My Muslim-American Body

status_message:
Today, the Supreme Court began hearing arguments in the first significant test of abortion rights in a decade. The Texas' AG claims that the law at the center of the case is meant "to improve the standard of care for abortion patients." 

But the real purpose, writes The Nation Magazine's Zoë Carpenter, is "to restrict abortion access." She adds: "The decision could make the procedure inaccessible for women who don't have the means to travel long distances, not just in Texas but in a number of other states that have passed similar laws, including Mississippi, Alabama, Louisiana, Kansas and Oklahoma."
link_name: ﻿The Big Lie at the Heart of the Texas Abortion Clinic Case

status_message:
There are "undeniable" downside risks of a Trump nomination, Brian Beutler writes at New Republic. 

BUT "they are far smaller than the salubrious effect his primary victory would have on the country if it forced upon Republicans the kind of reckoning the 2008 and 2012 elections didn't. 

If the politics of resentment were no longer readily available to them - lost to disgruntled Trump voters, or rendered toxic by the fact that they gave rise to Trump in the first place - Republicans might no longer interpret governing with Democrats as surrender."
link_name: Donald Trump's Nomination Will Have Real, Lasting Upsides

status_message:
Super Tuesday –> Frontrunners Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton did very well last night — but none of their opponents seem ready to throw in the towel. Marco Rubio won a state, and Ted Cruz won three. John Kasich came in a close second to Trump in Vermont. Bernie Sanders won four states: Minnesota, Colorado, Oklahoma and Vermont.

If the Republican Party hopes to stop Trump, they have 14 days left to get it together, writes Andrew Prokop at Vox: "After March 15, 58 percent of delegates will already be allotted. The bigger the lead Trump amasses in this period when so many delegates are at stake, the more likely it will be prohibitively difficult for any one candidate to catch up to him."
link_name: Morning Reads: The Frontrunners Win Big — But the Race Isn't Over - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Studies show that kids held in solitary confinement experience long-lasting psychological damage. Activists hope a wave of local and national policy changes means widespread reform is on the way, writes YES! Magazine.
link_name: 24 States Put Juvenile Offenders in Solitary, But Advocates Are Trying to Change That

status_message: In an editorial today The New York Times writes that once the primaries are over, the campaign finance machine will shift into high gear. "With only two nominees to back, tens of millions more from big donors will come sweeping into the race. Big Republican backers like the Koch brothers and Sheldon Adelson will come off the sidelines; other millionaires and billionaires will step up their super PAC giving."
link_name: Big-Donor Money Has Not Worked in the 2016 Campaign. Yet.

status_message:
A rise in the minimum wage has many different benefits for America's workers, but there's a major upside for the government too, according to the Economic Policy Institute's David Cooper. 

"A new report from the Economic Policy Institute indicates that raising the federal minimum wage to $12 by 2020 would lift wages for more than 35 million workers nationwide and generate about $17 billion annually in savings to government assistance programs."
link_name: How We Can Save $17 Billion in Public Assistance - Annually

status_message: Historian Andrew Bacevich on Donald Trump: "He is to American politics what Martin Shkreli is to Big Pharma. Each represents in exaggerated form the distilled essence of a much larger and more disturbing reality." Bacevich goes on to predict the major changes that will occur in America if Trump secures the Republican nomination -- and ultimately the US presidency.
link_name: Don't Cry for Me, America: What Trumpism Means for Democracy

status_message: Here's a quick explainer by NPR on what Super Tuesday is all about.
link_name: Super Tuesday: Here's What You Need To Know

status_message: $36 million –> Nicholas Confessore reports for The New York Times that's how much Bernie Sanders raised in February alone, a huge number even though his chances of winning the nomination, after today, might be slim. At The Washington Post, Paul Waldman writes that on this Super Tuesday the "stakes for him [Sanders] are incredibly high, much higher than for Hillary Clinton."
link_name: Morning Reads: The Super Tuesday Stakes for Sanders Are "Incredibly High" - BillMoyers.com

status_message: More than half a million Texas voters likely lack the right form of ID to vote on Super Tuesday. Texas is one of five Super Tuesday states where people might face barriers to voting as a result of voter ID laws. This year marks the first presidential election since SCOTUS struck down key sections of the Voting Rights Act.
link_name: On Super Tuesday, Hundreds of Thousands May Be Barred From Voting

status_message: The campaign of 2016 and 1896 have quite a bit in common, according to historian Bernard Weisberger. In an article pointing out the similarities between now and then, he writes:  "[T]he upper classes are sheltered not only by their ability to buy the governments of their choice, but also by a culture which adheres to the pseudo-science of Social Darwinism – 'the survival of the fittest' – and the companion academic fiction of 'the free market' which holds that any governmental attempt to interfere with its workings on behalf of the victims of unregulated capitalism's periodic crises is both counterproductive and wicked." So which year is he talking about?
link_name: The Year of the Populist Outsider: 1896

status_message: A federal judge in New York has ruled in favor of Apple, saying that a law from 1789 did not authorize him to force the tech giant to lift data from an iPhone. The Washington Post writes: "The ruling is not binding in any other court, but it takes on an outsize importance as the US government battles Apple in a separate case in California over whether the tech firm should help unlock a phone used by one of the shooters in the San Bernardino terrorist attack in December." While the two cases have significant differences, "they both turn on whether a law from 1789 known as the All Writs Act can be applied to cases in which the government cannot get at encrypted data stored on suspects' devices."
link_name: Judge rules in favor of Apple in key case involving a locked iPhone

status_message: The spirited debate about the merits of Bernie Sanders's economic plan reminds two prominent economists of one that they were on opposite sides of 35 years ago. Bruce Bartlett and James Galbraith write about the similarities to the debate on Ronald Reagan's economic plan -- and the lessons that apply today.
link_name: The Battle Over Reagan's Economic Plan

status_message: John Fetterman, mayor of Braddock, Pennsylvania, is described by The Guardian, as the "coolest mayor in America." He's hoping to win a US Senate seat so he can fight for forgotten "legacy cities" like the one he represents. An under-funded underdog, Fetterman is polling competitively, but can he win over his state's conservative, mostly white center, by wooing the rural working-class voters that have fled the Democratic Party?
link_name: Meet the Rust-Belt Populist Who Wants to Be Pennsylvania's Next Senator

status_message:
As Jonathan Chait notes this morning at New York Magazine, the language that Donald Trump is using to talk about David Duke and the Ku Klux Klan is reminiscient of another anti-immigrant campaign waged in 19th-century America. Chait writes:

"Four times in the interview [with Jake Tapper], he repeats the phrase 'I know nothing.' That is the exact wording used by 19th-century nativists. The 'Know-Nothing Party' is sometimes misremembered in the popular imagination today as signifying ignorance. In fact, the phrase was used by nativists who belonged to secret societies pledged to support only native-born Protestants for public office."

Here's more on Trump's campaign and its similarities to the campaign of The Know-Nothing Party from historian Bernie Weisberger.
link_name: For Immigrants – And All of Us – A Time to Fight

status_message:
Here comes Super Tuesday –> The single biggest primary day is nearly upon us, and the Republican Party establishment still is fighting against what increasingly looks like the inevitable: that Donald Trump will be their nominee. 

They did it to themselves –> Esquire's Charlie Pierce writes: "The party's three-decade courtship of the wild and the vile in our politics sooner or later was bound to leave the party open to a renegade campaign that was better at energizing that element than the cumbersome party machinery was."

AND ICYMI: The Brookings Institution's Robert Kagan made similar points last week in a column for The Washington Post. "Let's be clear: Trump is no fluke. Nor is he hijacking the Republican Party or the conservative movement, if there is such a thing. He is, rather, the party's creation, its Frankenstein's monster, brought to life by the party, fed by the party and now made strong enough to destroy its maker."
link_name: Morning Reads: The GOP's Last Ditch Effort to Stop Trump - BillMoyers.com

status_message: Congratulations to Spotlight Movie on winning Best Picture!
link_name: 'Spotlight' Celebrates Heroes of Investigative Reporting -- and Democracy

status_message: A growing number of cities across the country are raising wages for workers, but some state legislators are working to stop them from superseding the state minimum wage.
link_name: Congrats on That New Citywide Minimum Wage. Now Republicans Are Going to Try to Kill It.

status_message:
Trump's racism and xenophobia violates America's core beliefs — yet the media and many Americans are okay with it.

"The rise of Donald Trump to the presumptive Republican standard bearer for president in 2016 is an indictment of, and a profound danger to, the American republic.

The Founding Fathers were afraid of the excitability of the voters and their vulnerability to the appeal of demagogues. That is the reason for a Senate (which was originally appointed), intended to check those notorious hotheads in Congress, who are elected from districts every two years.

But it isn't only the checks and balances in government that are necessary to keep the republic. It is the Fourth Estate, i.e. the press, it is the country's leaders and it is the general public who stand between the republic and the rise of a Mussolini." - Juan Cole

Read more: http://billmoyers.com/story/how-the-us-went-fascist-mass-media-makes-excuses-for-trump-voters
link_name: How Mass Media Makes Excuses for Trump Voters

status_message:
Jennifer Rubin, a journalist who says she has "interviewed Chris Christie more times for more hours than any journalist outside of New Jersey" reacted to his endorsement of Donald Trump in an op-ed. She writes:

"I wrote recently that Trump's rise was enabled by many people just 'doing their jobs' — the mainstream media, talk show hosts, backbenchers in Congress, etc. But none will be as morally culpable as Christie if Trump succeeds. Why? Because he knows better, and because the threat — and it is a threat — of Trump as commander in chief, or anyone else unfit for that job, was a central motivation for Christie's run."
link_name: Chris Christie's despicable endorsement of Trump

status_message:
Establishment Republicans have been scrambling for a way to prevent Donald Trump from becoming the party's presidential nominee with no consensus on a way forward, reports The New York Times.

"Despite all the forces arrayed against Mr. Trump, the interviews show, the party has been gripped by a nearly incapacitating leadership vacuum and a paralytic sense of indecision and despair, as he has won smashing victories in South Carolina and Nevada."
link_name: Inside the Republican Party's Desperate Mission to Stop Donald Trump

status_message:
A post from historian Bernie Weisberger filed last September about Donald Trump's anti-immigrant rants is worth repeating in these days before Super Tuesday.

He reminds us that the story of our nation's long practice of welcoming immigrants is an American triumph, all the more so because it has been achieved over constant resistance. And he  argues we must fight again.
link_name: For Immigrants – And All of Us – A Time to Fight

status_message:
Buried beneath the breathless coverage of Donald Trump the candidate is some significant investigative journalism — both new and old — filled with facts. 

Just in time for the weekend, we bring you our roundup of stories about Donald Trump, the business man. 

It remains to be seen whether these facts can outpace the fiction in the 2016 race. As Walter Lippmann wrote, "There can be no higher law in journalism than to tell the truth and to shame the devil."
link_name: Weekend Reads: The Trump Files

status_message:

They're all pretty far to the right."

status_message:
The last 15 years demonstrate that no matter the military strength at your command, war no longer translates into power.

Could it be that war has in the most literal sense outlived its usefulness, at least for the United States?
link_name: War, What Is It Good For? Absolutely Nothing. Literally.

status_message:
"I am not sure that manners or character have all that much to do with governance. 

Some of our best presidents seem to have had questionable character, and some – think of Andrew Jackson – had bad manners. 

But values are different. Values define who we are, how we think about the world, and, most important of all, how we treat others. 

A candidate's values are not only important; they may be more important than anything else in the campaign, and possibly the surest guide to what that candidate would do in office. Policies may change. Values are bedrock. ...

"Trump vs. the Pope" was the headline everywhere. It made for great drama, but it missed the point. This wasn't about a religious figure taking on a political windbag. This was about the kind of values we want our leaders to have and the kind of people we want to be. That is much worthier of discussion than Trump vs. the Pope, mano a mano." - Neal Gabler

Read more: http://billmoyers.com/story/the-justice-the-pope-the-press-and-the-question-of-values/
link_name: The Justice, the Pope, the Press and the Question of Values

status_message:
Wolf Blitzer, tonight you will moderate the last Republican debate before the all-important Super Tuesday primary elections. 

You have the chance to be the FIRST journalist to seek the candidates' views on one subject that has never been discussed in a televised Republican debate or town hall: voter suppression, the passage in at least 16 states by Republican legislatures of new laws that make it more difficult for African Americans, Hispanics, Asian-Americans, students, the poor and disabled to cast a ballot. 

You can break new ground, forcing the candidates to reveal their views on one issue that may well affect the outcome of the presidential election. -  Gary May 

Please LIKE and SHARE if you agree that this is an important issue that needs to be included in tonight's debate.
link_name: Wolf Blitzer, Make the Candidates Talk About Voting Rights in Tonight's Debate

status_message:
"King Trump" –> Matt Taibbi has a long, entertaining and frightening read on Donald Trump at Rolling Stone. (In case you forgot, Taibbi is the journalist who in 2009 described Goldman Sachs as "a great vampire squid wrapped around the face of humanity, relentlessly jamming its blood funnel into anything that smells like money.")

Taibbi writes that what "tweedy Buckleyites at places like the [National] Review don't get is that most people don't give a damn about 'conservative principles.' Yes, millions of people responded to that rhetoric for years. But that wasn't because of the principle itself, but because it was always coupled with the more effective politics of resentment: Big-government liberals are to blame for your problems."
link_name: Morning Reads: President Trump. It Could Really Happen. - BillMoyers.com

status_message: And on a brighter note... President Obama has nominated Carla D. Hayden as the next librarian of Congress. If confirmed, she would be the first woman and first African-American ever to lead the world's largest library.
link_name: Obama Nominates Carla Hayden To Lead Library Of Congress

status_message:
"The rise of Donald Trump to the presumptive Republican standard bearer for president in 2016 is an indictment of, and a profound danger to, the American republic.

The Founding Fathers were afraid of the excitability of the voters and their vulnerability to the appeal of demagogues. That is the reason for a Senate (which was originally appointed), intended to check those notorious hotheads in Congress, who are elected from districts every two years.

But it isn't only the checks and balances in government that are necessary to keep the republic. It is the Fourth Estate, i.e. the press, it is the country's leaders and it is the general public who stand between the republic and the rise of a Mussolini.

The notables have been shown to be useless. 

Donald Trump should have been kicked out of the Republican Party the moment he began talking about violating the Constitution. 

The first time he hinted about assaulting the journalists covering his rallies, he should have been shown the door. When he openly advocated torture ("worse than waterboarding"), he should have been ushered away. When he began speaking of closing houses of worship, he should have been expelled. 

He has solemnly pledged to violate the First, Fourth and Eighth Amendments of the Constitution, at the least. If someone's platform is unconstitutional, it boggles the mind that a major American party would put him or her up for president. 

How can he take the oath of office with a straight face?" –Juan Cole

Read more: http://billmoyers.com/story/how-the-us-went-fascist-mass-media-makes-excuses-for-trump-voters/
link_name: How the US Went Fascist: Mass Media Makes Excuses for Trump Voters | By Juan Cole

status_message:
Nevada caucuses –> Trump won them, handily. 

Lynn Vavrek at The New York Times looks at Trump voters' intolerance — "the attitudes of Mr. Trump's supporters on things that he has not talked very much about on the campaign trail. He has said nothing about a ban on gays in the United States, the outcome of the Civil War or white supremacy. Yet on all of these topics, Mr. Trump's supporters appear to stand out from the rest of Republican primary voters… 

"Nearly 20 percent of Mr. Trump's voters disagreed with the freeing of slaves in Southern states after the Civil War. Only 5 percent of Mr. Rubio's voters share this view."

"Over the past several years, labor groups have launched dozens of campaigns to raise the minimum wage in many of the country's largest cities as well as less likely places like Louisville, Santa Fe and Albuquerque. The series of high-profile successes that followed provided a bright spot for workers' advocates and buoyed progressives' hopes of a resurgent, more nimble American labor movement.

But state lawmakers, mostly Republicans, are moving quickly to challenge the widening popularity of these local efforts with laws that prohibit local governments from setting their own wages."

Union leaders fret about internal surveys that show the billionaire is attracting greater support than is usually afforded Republicans."

status_message:
Maybe it's that 50,000-year-old, Neanderthal DNA scientists say a lot of us possess, but this feels like the most brutal, vicious and mendacious political year since the days when politicians traded jugs of corn whiskey for votes, fought duels, and flagellated opponents to near death with canes.

In last Saturday night's Republican debate, the words "lie," "lying" and "liar" were fired off by the candidates against each other like volleys in a paintball tournament.

On the other hand, statements that were, in fact, true were greeted with booing. Booing.

In one of his rare, stopped-watch-is-right-twice-a-day moments, Donald Trump said, "Obviously the war in Iraq was a big, fat mistake, all right? George Bush made a mistake, we can make mistakes. But that one was a beauty." Who could argue with that? Boos. ...

Have we so lost touch that the truth no longer sets us free but inspires braying derision? Have so-called "reality television," and social media plagued with trolling and conspiracy theories so melted our brains that when facts get in the way of whatever nonsense we prefer to believe, we bellow like wounded beasts? 

Read more: http://billmoyers.com/story/maybe-it-is-a-single-issue-election/
link_name: Maybe It IS a Single-Issue Election

status_message:
Here's the story so far. We have the chief legal representatives of the 8th and 16th largest economies on Earth (California and New York) probing the biggest fossil fuel company on Earth (ExxonMobil), while both Democratic presidential candidates are demanding that the DOJ join the investigation of what may prove to be one of the biggest corporate scandals in American history. 

And that's just the beginning. 

As bad as Exxon has been in the past, what it's doing now — entirely legally — is helping push the planet over the edge and into the biggest crisis in the entire span of the human story.
link_name: Exxon's Never-Ending Big Dig | By Bill McKibben

status_message:
It's been clear for some time that how long Americans live depends on how much money they have, even their zip codes.

A new study "adds to a growing body of evidence that there is a widening gap in health between the haves and have-nots in the country," said Steven Woolf, director of the Center on Society and Health at Virginia Commonwealth University.
link_name: Why Are Poor Americans Dying So Much Earlier Than Rich Americans?

status_message:
If you're a fan of the Netflix series Making A Murderer, you're familiar with the case of Brendan Dassey, a 16-year-old with a developmental disability, who was accused of rape and murder.

Dassey's case exemplifies exactly what the Supreme Court declared in the 1963 case, Gideon v. Wainwright: only with the aid of effective defense counsel is justice for all ensured. 

Police and prosecutors have been accused of using his cognitive limitations against him. Perhaps most troubling is the fact that Dassey's own lawyer — who had been appointed by the court — assumed that his client was guilty and refused to investigate his claims of innocence. Read more:
link_name: The Crucial Elements of Criminal Justice Reform That Nobody Is Talking About

status_message:
Multi-tasking –> Believing that television ads may not be the best use of their cash, super PACs are trying on new roles in the 2016 primaries, writes Byron Tau at The Wall Street Journal. Super PAC staffers are going door to door, canvassing for candidates, and conducting opposition research — tasks that were formerly carried out by the campaigns themselves. Unlike super PACs, however, campaigns are not free to accept unlimited sums from wealthy donors to fund these efforts.

AND: In a recent report, the Campaign Finance Institute finds that "Million-Dollar Donors Gave 24% of Money for all candidates and their Super PACs, 42% for Cruz, 38% for Rubio."
link_name: Morning Reads: The Next Nominating Contests Are Tomorrow; Super PACs More Hands On in Campaigns...

status_message: Good lawmakers borrow, great lawmakers steal. Rep. David Scott (D-Ga.) is a great lawmaker.

status_message:
It is generally attributed to voter dissatisfaction the dysfunction of our politics that Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders are topping the polls, but you can't blame politicians alone. 

Political journalists also play an enormous role in creating a sense of malaise, distrust and division, and it stems not only from what they do but also from what they don't do.

The media's "horse race" approach to the presidential election not only ignores the issues, it's also dangerous for democracy, writes Neal Gabler.
link_name: Political Coverage 2016: Contempt on the Campaign Trail

Hillary Clinton spoke in Harlem earlier this week about the "school-to-prison pipeline" and offered new proposals aimed at ending it, such as overhauling school discipline and criminal justice procedures, universal preschool, and $125 billion to revitalize underserved communities, among others.
